Islands</a> (four of which are <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands_dispute" title="Kuril Islands dispute">disputed with Japan</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Arctic&#95;239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arctic-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Diomede_Islands" title="Diomede Islands">Diomede Islands</a>, administered by Russia and the United States, are just 3.8&#160;km (2.4&#160;mi) apart;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kunashir_Island" class="mw-redirect" title="Kunashir Island">Kunashir Island</a> of the Kuril Islands is merely 20&#160;km (12.4&#160;mi) from <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>, Japan.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Chapple-2019&#95;2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chapple-2019-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia, home of over 100,000 rivers,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-natgeo&#95;228-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> has one of the world's largest surface water resources, with its lakes containing approximately one-quarter of the world's liquid <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical&#95;Environment&#95;227-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical_Environment-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Baikal" title="Lake Baikal">Lake Baikal</a>, the largest and most prominent among Russia's fresh water bodies, is the world's deepest, purest, oldest and most capacious fresh water lake, containing over one-fifth of the world's fresh surface water.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Ladoga" title="Lake Ladoga">Ladoga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Onega" title="Lake Onega">Onega</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Russia" title="Northwest Russia">northwestern Russia</a> are two of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_lakes_of_Europe" title="List of largest lakes of Europe">largest lakes in Europe</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-natgeo&#95;228-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is second only to Brazil by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_renewable_water_resources" title="List of countries by total renewable water resources">total renewable water resources</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Volga" title="Volga">Volga</a> in western Russia, widely regarded as Russia's national river, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Europe#Rivers_of_Europe_by_length" title="List of rivers of Europe">longest river</a> in Europe and forms the <a href="/wiki/Volga_Delta" title="Volga Delta">Volga Delta</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">river delta</a> in the continent.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Siberian rivers of <a href="/wiki/Ob_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Ob River">Ob</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yenisey" class="mw-redirect" title="Yenisey">Yenisey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lena_River" title="Lena River">Lena</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Amur_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Amur River">Amur</a> are among the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length" class="mw-redirect" title="List of rivers by length">longest rivers</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate">Climate</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Russia" title="Climate of Russia">Climate of Russia</a></div>
<p>The size of Russia and the remoteness of many of its areas from the sea result in the dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> throughout most of the country, except for the tundra and the extreme southwest. Mountain ranges in the south and east obstruct the flow of warm air masses from the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian</a> and Pacific oceans, while the <a href="/wiki/European_Plain" title="European Plain">European Plain</a> spanning its west and north opens it to influence from the Atlantic and Arctic oceans.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical&#95;Environment&#95;227-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical_Environment-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most of northwest Russia and Siberia have a <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">subarctic climate</a>, with extremely severe winters in the inner regions of northeast Siberia (mostly <a href="/wiki/Sakha_Republic" title="Sakha Republic">Sakha</a>, where the Northern <a href="/wiki/Pole_of_Cold" title="Pole of Cold">Pole of Cold</a> is located with the record low temperature of 71.2&#160;C or 96.2&#160;F),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Arctic&#95;239-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arctic-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and more moderate winters elsewhere. Russia's vast coastline along the Arctic Ocean and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Arctic_islands" title="Russian Arctic islands">Russian Arctic islands</a> have a <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">polar climate</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical&#95;Environment&#95;227-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical_Environment-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/500px-Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" decoding="async" width="350" height="280" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/960px-Russia_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="792" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Kppen climate classification">Kppen climate classification</a> of Russia</figcaption></figure>
<p>The coastal part of <a href="/wiki/Krasnodar_Krai" title="Krasnodar Krai">Krasnodar Krai</a> on the Black Sea, most notably <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, and some coastal and interior strips of the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a> possess a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> with mild and wet winters.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical&#95;Environment&#95;227-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical_Environment-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In many regions of East Siberia and the Russian Far East, winter is dry compared to summer, while other parts of the country experience more even precipitation across seasons. Winter precipitation in most parts of the country usually falls as snow. The westernmost parts of Kaliningrad Oblast and some parts in the south of Krasnodar Krai and the North Caucasus have an <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical&#95;Environment&#95;227-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical_Environment-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The region along the Lower Volga and Caspian Sea coast, as well as some southernmost slivers of Siberia, possess a <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout much of the territory, there are only two distinct seasons, winter and summer, as spring and autumn are usually brief.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical&#95;Environment&#95;227-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998125135Physical_Environment-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The coldest month is January (February on the coastline); the warmest is usually July. Great ranges of temperature are typical. In winter, temperatures get colder both from south to north and from west to east. Summers can be quite hot, even in Siberia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Russia" title="Climate change in Russia">Climate change in Russia</a> is causing more frequent <a href="/wiki/Wildfires_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildfires in Russia">wildfires</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and thawing the country's large expanse of <a href="/wiki/Permafrost" title="Permafrost">permafrost</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Russia" title="Wildlife of Russia">Wildlife of Russia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_in_Russia" title="List of ecoregions in Russia">List of ecoregions in Russia</a></div>
<p>Russia, owing to its gigantic size, has diverse ecosystems, including <a href="/wiki/Polar_desert" title="Polar desert">polar deserts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Forest-tundra" title="Forest-tundra">forest-tundra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forests" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests">mixed and broadleaf forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/Forest_steppe" title="Forest steppe">forest steppe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>, semi-desert, and <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropics</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-climate&#95;250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> About half of Russia's territory is forested,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and it has the world's largest area of forest.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Gardiner-2021&#95;251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gardiner-2021-251"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/250px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/500px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1549" data-file-height="1037" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Yugyd_Va_National_Park" title="Yugyd Va National Park">Yugyd Va National Park</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Komi_Republic" title="Komi Republic">Komi Republic</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national park</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-urals&#95;236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-urals-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Russian biodiversity includes 12,500 species of <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plants</a>, 2,200 species of <a href="/wiki/Bryophyte" title="Bryophyte">bryophytes</a>, about 3,000 species of <a href="/wiki/Lichen" title="Lichen">lichens</a>, 7,0009,000 species of <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a>, and 20,00025,000 species of fungi. Russian <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> is composed of <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Russia" title="List of mammals of Russia">320 species</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mammals" class="mw-redirect" title="Mammals">mammals</a>, over <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Russia" title="List of birds of Russia">732 species</a> of birds, 75 species of reptiles, about 30 species of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibians</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_freshwater_fish_of_Russia" title="List of freshwater fish of Russia">343 species</a> of <a href="/wiki/Freshwater_fish" title="Freshwater fish">freshwater fish</a> (high <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemism</a>), approximately 1,500 species of <a href="/wiki/Saltwater_fish" title="Saltwater fish">saltwater fishes</a>, 9 species of <a href="/wiki/Cyclostomata" class="mw-redirect" title="Cyclostomata">cyclostomata</a>, and approximately 100150,000 <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">invertebrates</a> (high endemism).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-climate&#95;250-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Approximately 1,100 rare and endangered plant and animal species are included in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Data_Book_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Red Data Book of the Russian Federation">Russian Red Data Book</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-climate&#95;250-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's entirely natural ecosystems are conserved in nearly 15,000 specially protected natural territories of various statuses, occupying more than 10% of the country's total area.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-climate&#95;250-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They include 45 <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Biosphere reserve">biosphere reserves</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 64 <a href="/wiki/National_parks_of_Russia" title="National parks of Russia">national parks</a>, and 101 <a href="/wiki/Zapovednik" title="Zapovednik">nature reserves</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Although in decline, the country still has many ecosystems which are still considered <a href="/wiki/Intact_forest_landscape" title="Intact forest landscape">intact forest</a>, mainly in the northern taiga areas, and the subarctic tundra of Siberia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia had a <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 9.02 in 2019, ranking 10th out of 172 countries, and the first ranked major nation globally.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Russia" title="Politics of Russia">Politics of Russia</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .multiimageinner span:not(.skin-invert-image):not(.skin-invert):not(.bg-transparent) img{background-color:white}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:191px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_(2025-09-30).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%282025-09-30%29.jpg/250px-%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%282025-09-30%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="192" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%282025-09-30%29.jpg/330px-%D0%92%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%80_%D0%9F%D1%83%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%282025-09-30%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="906" data-file-height="1160" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Russian_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="President of the Russian Federation">President</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:136px;max-width:136px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:191px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B8%D0%BB_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_(18-11-2025).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B8%D0%BB_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%2818-11-2025%29.jpg/250px-%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B8%D0%BB_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%2818-11-2025%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="134" height="191" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B8%D0%BB_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%2818-11-2025%29.jpg/330px-%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B8%D0%BB_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%83%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD_%2818-11-2025%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="440" data-file-height="627" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Mishustin" title="Mikhail Mishustin">Mikhail Mishustin</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_Russian_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="Prime Minister of the Russian Federation">Prime Minister</a></small></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russia, by constitution, is a <a href="/wiki/Symmetric_federalism" title="Symmetric federalism">symmetric federal</a> republic with a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a>, wherein the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">president</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-(Article&#95;80,&#95;&#95;1)&#95;257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-(Article_80,__1)-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia" title="Prime Minister of Russia">prime minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998383428Chapter&#95;7.&#95;Government&#95;and&#95;Politics&#95;258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998383428Chapter_7._Government_and_Politics-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is structured as a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998383428Chapter&#95;7.&#95;Government&#95;and&#95;Politics&#95;258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998383428Chapter_7._Government_and_Politics-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with the federal government composed of three branches:<sup id="cite&#95;ref-DeRouen-2005&#95;259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouen-2005-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Legislative: The <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_Assembly_(Russia)" title="Federal Assembly (Russia)">Federal Assembly of Russia</a>, made up of the 450-member <a href="/wiki/State_Duma" title="State Duma">State Duma</a> and the 170-member <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia)" title="Federation Council (Russia)">Federation Council</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-DeRouen-2005&#95;259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouen-2005-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> adopts <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves treaties, has the <a href="/wiki/Power_of_the_purse" title="Power of the purse">power of the purse</a> and the power of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_in_Russia" title="Impeachment in Russia">impeachment</a> of the president.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-constitution.ru.ch5&#95;260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution.ru.ch5-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Executive: The president is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander-in-Chief_of_the_Russian_Armed_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Commander-in-Chief of the Russian Armed Forces">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Armed Forces</a>, and appoints the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Russia">Government of Russia</a> (Cabinet) and other officers, who administer and enforce federal laws and policies.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-(Article&#95;80,&#95;&#95;1)&#95;257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-(Article_80,__1)-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The president may issue <a href="/wiki/Decree_of_the_President_of_Russia" title="Decree of the President of Russia">decrees of unlimited scope</a>, so long as they do not contradict the constitution or federal law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Russia" title="Judiciary of Russia">Judiciary</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Russia" title="Constitutional Court of Russia">Constitutional Court</a>, <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Russia" title="Supreme Court of Russia">Supreme Court</a> and lower federal courts, whose judges are appointed by the Federation Council on the recommendation of the president,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-DeRouen-2005&#95;259-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DeRouen-2005-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> interpret laws and can overturn laws they deem <a href="/wiki/Constitutionality" title="Constitutionality">unconstitutional</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></li></ul>
<p>The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term and may be elected no more than twice.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>i<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ministries of the government are composed of the premier and his deputies, ministers, and selected other individuals; all are appointed by the president on the recommendation of the prime minister (whereas the appointment of the latter requires the consent of the State Duma). <a href="/wiki/United_Russia" title="United Russia">United Russia</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Dominant-party_system#Eurasia" title="Dominant-party system">dominant</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Russia" title="List of political parties in Russia">political party in Russia</a>, and has been described as "<a href="/wiki/Big_tent" title="Big tent">big tent</a>" and the "<a href="/wiki/Party_of_power" title="Party of power">party of power</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Political_history">Political history</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg/330px-Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="233" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg/500px-Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg/960px-Chart_Constitution_of_Russia_EN.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1052" data-file-height="744" /></a><figcaption>A chart of the political system in the modern Russian Federation</figcaption></figure>
<p>While there is scholarly debate over the significance of the <i><a href="/wiki/Veche" title="Veche">veche</a></i> in the Middle Ages as a representative political body,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russian society has historically been ruled by various forms of <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocracy</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-u511&#95;269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-u511-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This pattern of a <a href="/wiki/Centralized_government" title="Centralized government">centralised ruling system</a> has its roots in the late Middle Ages, with a unified Russian state being established as an <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a> in the late 15th century,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> a governance structure that was followed until the early 20th century.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following the 1917 Russian Revolution, the monarchy was abolished, and the Soviet Union was proclaimed as a <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist state</a> until its collapse.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-u511&#95;269-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-u511-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Brief periods of non-autocratic rule include the short-lived <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Provisional Government</a> in 1917 established during the <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a>, and during the transition of post-Soviet Russia into a <a href="/wiki/Flawed_democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Flawed democracy">flawed democracy</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Boris_Yeltsin" title="Presidency of Boris Yeltsin">presidency of Boris Yeltsin</a> in the 1990s.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-w330&#95;273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-w330-273"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-h185&#95;274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-h185-274"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Croissant&#95;275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Croissant-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 223">&#58;&#8202;223&#8202;</span></sup> 
</p><p>In the 21st century, following the <a href="/wiki/Russia_under_Vladimir_Putin" title="Russia under Vladimir Putin">presidencies of Vladimir Putin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Presidency of Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a>, Russia has experienced significant <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding" title="Democratic backsliding">democratic backsliding</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Croissant&#95;275-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Croissant-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 223">&#58;&#8202;223&#8202;</span></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The political system evolved from <a href="/wiki/Electoral_authoritarianism" class="mw-redirect" title="Electoral authoritarianism">electoral authoritarianism</a> into a consolidated <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian_regime" class="mw-redirect" title="Authoritarian regime">authoritarian regime</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Croissant&#95;275-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Croissant-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 323">&#58;&#8202;323&#8202;</span></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-t305&#95;278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t305-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some political scientists have characterised Putin as the head of a <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship" title="Dictatorship">dictatorship</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kuzio-2016&#95;9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kuzio-2016-9"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Krzywdzinski&#95;10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Krzywdzinski-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> or a personalist regime.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-t305&#95;278-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-t305-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Putin's second tenure as president has led to further autocratization,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Croissant&#95;275-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Croissant-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 512">&#58;&#8202;512&#8202;</span></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Mamaev&#95;282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mamaev-282"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Pages: 8081">&#58;&#8202;8081&#8202;</span></sup> which has been the most significant since the Soviet era,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with some authors suggesting a regeneration of <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">totalitarian</a> elements.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Putin's ruling policies are generally referred to as <a href="/wiki/Putinism" title="Putinism">Putinism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Political_divisions">Political divisions</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_divisions_of_Russia" title="Political divisions of Russia">Political divisions of Russia</a></div>
<p>Russia, by constitution, is a <a href="/wiki/Symmetric_federalism" title="Symmetric federalism">symmetric (with the possibility of an asymmetric configuration) federation</a>. Unlike the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_federalism" title="Asymmetric federalism">asymmetric model</a> of the RSFSR, where only republics were "subjects of the federation", the current constitution raised the status of other regions to the level of republics and made all regions equal with the title "subject of the federation". The regions of Russia have reserved areas of competence, but regions do not have sovereignty, do not have the status of a sovereign state, do not have the right to indicate any sovereignty in their constitutions and do not have the right to secede from the country. The laws of the regions cannot contradict federal laws.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Federal_subjects_of_Russia" title="Federal subjects of Russia">federal subjects</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-disputed&#95;289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-disputed-289"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>j<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> have equal representationtwo delegates eachin the <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia)" title="Federation Council (Russia)">Federation Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">upper house</a> of the Federal Assembly.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-constitution.ru.ch5&#95;260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution.ru.ch5-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They do, however, differ in the degree of <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_administrative_division" title="Autonomous administrative division">autonomy</a> they enjoy.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Federal_districts_of_Russia" title="Federal districts of Russia">federal districts of Russia</a> were established by Putin in 2000 to facilitate central government control of the federal subjects.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Originally seven, currently there are eight federal districts, each headed by an envoy appointed by the president.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File/Frameless"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_(2022),_disputed_Crimea_and_Donbass.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282022%29%2C_disputed_Crimea_and_Donbass.svg/960px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282022%29%2C_disputed_Crimea_and_Donbass.svg.png" decoding="async" width="600" height="330" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282022%29%2C_disputed_Crimea_and_Donbass.svg/1280px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282022%29%2C_disputed_Crimea_and_Donbass.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="282" /></a><figcaption></figcaption></figure>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Federal subjects
</th>
<th>Governance
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFEC77; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;46&#160;<a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Russia" title="Oblasts of Russia">oblasts</a></div>
</td>
<td>The most common type of federal subject with a governor and locally elected legislature. Commonly named after their administrative centres.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00C160; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;22&#160;<a href="/wiki/Republics_of_Russia" title="Republics of Russia">republics</a></div>
</td>
<td>Each is nominally autonomoushome to a specific <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia" title="Ethnic groups in Russia">ethnic minority</a>, and has its own constitution, language, and legislature, but is represented by the federal government in international affairs.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF9400; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;9&#160;<a href="/wiki/Krais_of_Russia" title="Krais of Russia">krais</a></div>
</td>
<td>For all intents and purposes, krais are legally identical to oblasts. The title "krai" ("frontier" or "territory") is historic, related to geographic (frontier) position in a certain period of history. The current krais are not related to frontiers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#006989; color:white;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;4&#160;<a href="/wiki/Autonomous_okrugs_of_Russia" title="Autonomous okrugs of Russia">autonomous okrugs</a></div>
</td>
<td>Occasionally referred to as "autonomous district", "autonomous area", and "autonomous region", each with a substantial or predominant ethnic minority.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF0037; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;3&#160;<a href="/wiki/Federal_cities_of_Russia" title="Federal cities of Russia">federal cities</a></div>
</td>
<td>Major cities that function as separate regions (Moscow and Saint Petersburg, as well as <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a> in Russian-occupied Ukraine).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#C300FF; color:black;-webkit-print-color-adjust: exact; print-color-adjust: exact;">&#160;</span>&#160;1&#160;autonomous oblast</div>
</td>
<td>The only autonomous oblast is the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Autonomous_Oblast" title="Jewish Autonomous Oblast">Jewish Autonomous Oblast</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Russia" title="Foreign relations of Russia">Foreign relations of Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg/330px-Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="168" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg/500px-Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg/960px-Russian-list-of-unfriendly-countries.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="260" /></a><figcaption><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="forced-color-adjust: none; background-color:#3F48CC; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;</span> Russia <br /> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" /><span class="legend nowrap"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="forced-color-adjust: none; background-color:#AA0000; color:white;">&#160;</span>&#160;</span> Countries on Russia's "<a href="/wiki/Unfriendly_countries_and_territories_list" title="Unfriendly countries and territories list">unfriendly countries and territories list</a>". <br /> The list includes Russia's geopolitical rivalsmember states of the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Member states of the European Union">European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_NATO" title="Member states of NATO">NATO</a> and their alliesthat have imposed <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="International sanctions during the Russo-Ukrainian War">sanctions against it</a> for its invasion of Ukraine.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Russia has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_diplomatic_missions" title="List of countries by number of diplomatic missions">sixth-largest diplomatic network</a> in the world as of 2024<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>. It maintains diplomatic relations with 187 <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">United Nations member states</a>, two <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">partially-recognised states</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and two <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations#Observers_and_non-members" title="Member states of the United Nations">United Nations observer states</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Russian_embassies" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian embassies">143 embassies</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As the <a href="/wiki/Succession_of_the_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Succession of the Soviet Union">legal successor of the Soviet Union</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998429486Chapter&#95;8.&#95;Foreign&#95;Relations&#95;301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998429486Chapter_8._Foreign_Relations-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_and_the_United_Nations" title="Soviet Union and the United Nations">retains its seat</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent member of the United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is generally described by political analysts as a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-gambit&#95;303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gambit-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-l454&#95;305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-l454-305"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is also a former <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">superpower</a> as the leading constituent of the former Soviet Union.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Reiman-2016&#95;156-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reiman-2016-156"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 21st century, many scholars view its global influence as being in decline.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-f495&#95;308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f495-308"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Nevertheless, Russia is a member state of the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, <a href="/wiki/WTO" class="mw-redirect" title="WTO">WTO</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>; and the leading member state of organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Union" title="Eurasian Economic Union">EAEU</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Collective_Security_Treaty_Organisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Collective Security Treaty Organisation">CSTO</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It was also a member state of the <a href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">G8</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a>) and part of the <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_Council_of_Europe" title="Russia in the Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> before its expulsion from the two groups in 2014 and 2022, respectively.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia maintains close relations <a href="/wiki/Belarus%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="BelarusRussia relations">with neighbouring Belarus</a>, which is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Union_State" title="Union State">Union State</a>, a supranational confederation of the two states.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> has been a <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Serbia_relations" title="RussiaSerbia relations">historically close ally</a> of Russia, as both countries share a strong mutual cultural, ethnic, and religious affinity.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From the 21st century, relations between Russia and China have significantly <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="ChinaRussia relations">strengthened bilaterally and economically</a> due to shared political interests.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is the largest customer of Russian military equipment, and the two countries share a strong <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="IndiaRussia relations">strategic and diplomatic relationship</a> since the Soviet era.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia wields significant political influence across the <a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">geopolitically</a> important <a href="/wiki/South_Caucasus" title="South Caucasus">South Caucasus</a> and Central Asia,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> described in Russia as the "<a href="/wiki/Near_abroad" title="Near abroad">near abroad</a>",<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998429486Chapter&#95;8.&#95;Foreign&#95;Relations&#95;301-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998429486Chapter_8._Foreign_Relations-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Kolst&#95;320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kolst-320"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while foreign political analysts have described the two regions as being part of Russia's "backyard".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia shares a complex <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="RussiaTurkey relations">strategic, energy, and defence relationship</a> with <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It maintains <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="IranRussia relations">cordial relations</a> with Iran, as it is a strategic and economic ally.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has also significantly developed its <a href="/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="North KoreaRussia relations">relations with North Korea</a> following its invasion of Ukraine in 2022, with increased defence co-operation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At the same time, its relations with <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations" title="RussiaUkraine relations">neighbouring Ukraine</a> and the Western worldspecifically the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="RussiaUnited States relations">United States</a> and the collective countries of the <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="RussiaEuropean Union relations">European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO%E2%80%93Russia_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="NATORussia relations">NATO</a>have collapsed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg/250px-2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg/500px-2019_Foto_de_fam%C3%ADlia_dos_L%C3%ADderes_do_G20.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3506" data-file-height="2337" /></a><figcaption>Putin with G20 counterparts in <a href="/wiki/Osaka" title="Osaka">Osaka</a>, 2019</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the 21st century, Russia has pursued an aggressive foreign policy aimed at securing <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional dominance</a> in Europe and increasing its international influence, as well as increasing domestic support for the government. It has initiated military interventions in the <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a> of Georgia and Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Russian_intervention_in_the_Syrian_civil_war" title="Russian intervention in the Syrian civil war">as well as in Syria</a> during its <a href="/wiki/Syrian_civil_war" title="Syrian civil war">prolonged civil war</a> in a bid to increase its influence in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and achieve its great power ambitions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Two-thirds of the global population, specifically the <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing countries</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Global_South" class="mw-redirect" title="Global South">Global South</a>, are either neutral or leaning towards Russia politically.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russian state-funded <a href="/wiki/Wagner_Group" title="Wagner Group">Wagner Group</a> has been <a href="/wiki/Wagner_Group_activities_in_Africa" title="Wagner Group activities in Africa">deployed in Africa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Africa_Corps_(Russia)" title="Africa Corps (Russia)">Africa Corps</a>),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Wagner_Group_activities_in_Syria" title="Wagner Group activities in Syria">in Syria</a>;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> to maintain political stability in <a href="/wiki/Failed_state" title="Failed state">failed states</a> through military projection and exploit local natural resources.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has also increasingly pushed to expand its influence across the <a href="/wiki/Arctic" title="Arctic">Arctic</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Asia%E2%80%93Pacific" class="mw-redirect" title="AsiaPacific">AsiaPacific</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has also continued using subversive tactics in its rival countries to project its geopolitical power,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-gambit&#95;303-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gambit-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> such as <a href="/wiki/Cyberwarfare_by_Russia" title="Cyberwarfare by Russia">cyberwarfare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_disinformation" title="Russian disinformation">disinformation campaigns</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sabotage" title="Sabotage">sabotage</a> attacks,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_assassinations" title="List of Russian assassinations">assassination attempts</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Violations_of_non-combatant_airspaces_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Violations of non-combatant airspaces during the Russian invasion of Ukraine">airspace violations</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> electoral interferences,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> nuclear saber-rattling,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_hybrid_warfare" title="Russian hybrid warfare">hybrid warfare</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-r890&#95;347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-r890-347"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Military">Military</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Russian Armed Forces</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_Design_Bureau,_054,_Sukhoi_T-50_(Su-57_prototype)_(49581303977).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_T-50_%28Su-57_prototype%29_%2849581303977%29.jpg/250px-Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_T-50_%28Su-57_prototype%29_%2849581303977%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_T-50_%28Su-57_prototype%29_%2849581303977%29.jpg/500px-Sukhoi_Design_Bureau%2C_054%2C_Sukhoi_T-50_%28Su-57_prototype%29_%2849581303977%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-57" title="Sukhoi Su-57">Sukhoi Su-57</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Fifth-generation_fighter" title="Fifth-generation fighter">fifth-generation fighter</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Air_Force" title="Russian Air Force">Russian Air Force</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Russian Armed Forces are divided into the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Ground_Forces" title="Russian Ground Forces">Ground Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Navy" title="Russian Navy">Navy</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Aerospace_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Aerospace Force">Aerospace Forces</a>and there are also two independent arms of service: the <a href="/wiki/Strategic_Missile_Troops" class="mw-redirect" title="Strategic Missile Troops">Strategic Missile Troops</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Airborne_Troops" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Airborne Troops">Airborne Troops</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998487552Chapter&#95;9.&#95;The&#95;Armed&#95;Forces&#95;349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998487552Chapter_9._The_Armed_Forces-349"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2025<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the military have 1.1 million active-duty personnel, which is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">fifth-largest</a>, and about 1.5 million <a href="/wiki/Military_reserve_force" title="Military reserve force">reserve personnel</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is mandatory for all male citizens aged 1827 to be <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">drafted</a> for a year of service in the Armed Forces.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is among the five <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">recognised</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear-weapons states</a>, with the world's <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">largest stockpile of nuclear weapons</a>; over half of the world's nuclear weapons are owned by Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia possesses the second-largest fleet of <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">ballistic missile submarines</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and is one of the only three countries operating <a href="/wiki/Strategic_bomber" title="Strategic bomber">strategic bombers</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Russia maintains the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by military expenditures">third-highest military expenditure</a>, spending $109 billion, corresponding to about 5.9% of its GDP.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-SIPRI&#95;354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI-354"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It was also the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_arms_exports" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by arms exports">third-largest arms exporter</a> in 20202024,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and has a large and indigenous <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Defense industry of Russia">defence industry</a>, which produces the majority of its military equipment.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Law,_corruption_and_crime"><span id="Law.2C_corruption_and_crime"></span>Law, corruption and crime</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Russia" title="Law of Russia">Law of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Russia" title="Law enforcement in Russia">Law enforcement in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Russia" title="Crime in Russia">Crime in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">Corruption in Russia</a></div>
<p>Post-Soviet Russia under the regime of Vladimir Putin has been governed by a form of <a href="/wiki/Crony_capitalism" title="Crony capitalism">crony capitalism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-crony&#95;359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-crony-359"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its political system has been variously described as a <a href="/wiki/Kleptocracy" title="Kleptocracy">kleptocracy</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> an <a href="/wiki/Oligarchy" title="Oligarchy">oligarchy</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Plutocracy" title="Plutocracy">plutocracy</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-crony&#95;359-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-crony-359"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2024<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, it is the lowest rated European country in <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s annual <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>, ranking 154th out of the 180 countries listed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Alexei_Navalny_marching_in_2017.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Alexei_Navalny_marching_in_2017.jpg/250px-Alexei_Navalny_marching_in_2017.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Alexei_Navalny_marching_in_2017.jpg/500px-Alexei_Navalny_marching_in_2017.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4177" data-file-height="2785" /></a><figcaption>Opposition leader <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Navalny" title="Alexei Navalny">Alexei Navalny</a> leading protestors in Moscow in the nationwide <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests" title="20172018 Russian protests">anti-corruption protests of 20172018</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Corruption has significantly increased following the collapse of the Soviet Union,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-SuharaManabu&#95;364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SuharaManabu-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and is seen as a significant issue in society.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-markus&#95;365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-markus-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It affects various sectors, including the economy,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-markus&#95;365-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-markus-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Government of Russia">government</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-SuharaManabu&#95;364-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SuharaManabu-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Russia" title="Law enforcement in Russia">law enforcement</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">healthcare</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">education</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the military.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia's <a href="/wiki/Informal_economy" title="Informal economy">shadow economy</a> was estimated to be about 44% of the total GDP in 2018.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_penal_military_units_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian penal military units during the Russian invasion of Ukraine">Penal military units</a> have been deployed as <a href="/wiki/Shock_troops" title="Shock troops">storm troops</a> during the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War since 2022, such as the <a href="/wiki/Storm-Z" title="Storm-Z">Storm-Z</a> and <a href="/wiki/Storm-V" title="Storm-V">Storm-V</a> units.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to estimates by the BBC, around 48,000 prisoners were recruited to fight for the Wagner Group.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The primary and fundamental statement of laws in Russia is the constitution. Statutes, such as the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_Code" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Civil Code">Russian Civil Code</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Criminal_Code" class="mw-redirect"
