title="Russian Criminal Code">Russian Criminal Code</a>, are the predominant legal sources of Russian law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_incarceration_rate" title="List of countries by incarceration rate">largest incarcerated population</a> in Europe, and the fifth-largest incarcerated population in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-icjpr&#95;378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-icjpr-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its incarceration rate is among the highest in Europe,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> although the number has fallen steadily, by 59% since 2000.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-icjpr&#95;378-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-icjpr-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Russia's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_intentional_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by intentional homicide rate">intentional homicide rate</a> stood at 6.8 per 100,000 people.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, Russia had the world's second-largest illegal arms trade market, after the United States, was described as a key hub for human trafficking, and was ranked first in Europe and 19th globally in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Organized_Crime_Index" title="Global Organized Crime Index">Global Organized Crime Index</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Human_rights">Human rights</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Russia" title="Human rights in Russia">Human rights in Russia</a></div>
<p>Violations of human rights in Russia have been increasingly reported by leading democracy and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_group" title="Human rights group">human rights groups</a>. In particular, <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> say that Russia is not democratic and allows few political rights and civil liberties to its citizens.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2004, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> has ranked Russia as "not free" in its <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a></i> survey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> has ranked Russia as an "authoritarian regime" in its <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>, ranking it 150th out of 167 countries in 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In regards to <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Russia" title="Media freedom in Russia">media freedom</a>, Russia was ranked 162nd out of 180 countries in <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>' <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> for 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Russian government has been widely criticised by political dissidents and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_defender" title="Human rights defender">human rights activists</a> for <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Russia" title="Elections in Russia">unfair elections</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> crackdowns on <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_Vladimir_Putin_in_Russia" title="Opposition to Vladimir Putin in Russia">opposition political parties and protests</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_undesirable_organizations_law" title="Russian undesirable organizations law">persecution of non-governmental organisations</a> and enforced suppression and <a href="/wiki/List_of_journalists_killed_in_Russia" title="List of journalists killed in Russia">killings of independent journalists</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_the_Russian_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="Censorship in the Russian Federation">censorship</a> of mass media and <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Russia" title="Internet censorship in Russia">internet</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_(Yekaterinburg,_February_24,_2022).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg/250px-Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg/500px-Protest_against_the_invasion_of_Ukraine_%28Yekaterinburg%2C_February_24%2C_2022%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304" /></a><figcaption>Following the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anti-war_protests_in_Russia_(2022%E2%80%93present)" title="Anti-war protests in Russia (2022present)">anti-war protests</a> broke out across Russia. The protests have been met with widespread repression, leading to about 15,000 people being arrested.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Muslims, especially <a href="/wiki/Salafi_movement" title="Salafi movement">Salafis</a>, have faced persecution in Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> To quash the <a href="/wiki/Insurgency_in_the_North_Caucasus" title="Insurgency in the North Caucasus">insurgency in the North Caucasus</a>, Russian authorities have been accused of indiscriminate killings,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> arrests, forced disappearances, and torture of civilians.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>, some Salafis along with facing government harassment based on their appearance, have had their homes blown up in counterinsurgency operations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Chechens and <a href="/wiki/Ingush_people" title="Ingush people">Ingush</a> in <a href="/wiki/Russian_prisons" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian prisons">Russian prisons</a> reportedly take more abuse than other ethnic groups.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Russia has set up <a href="/wiki/Russian_filtration_camps_for_Ukrainians" title="Russian filtration camps for Ukrainians">filtration camps</a> where many Ukrainians are subjected to abuses and forcibly sent to Russia; the camps have been compared to <a href="/wiki/Filtration_camp_system_in_Chechnya" title="Filtration camp system in Chechnya">those used in the Chechen Wars</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Political repression also increased following the start of the invasion, with <a href="/wiki/Russian_2022_war_censorship_laws" title="Russian 2022 war censorship laws">laws adopted</a> that establish punishments for "discrediting" the armed forces.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia has introduced several restrictions on <a href="/wiki/LGBTQ_rights_in_Russia" title="LGBTQ rights in Russia">LGBTQ rights</a>. In 2013, an <a href="/wiki/Russian_anti-LGBTQ_law" title="Russian anti-LGBTQ law">anti-LGBTQ law</a> banning "gay propaganda" was unanimously passed by the State Duma and the Federation Council, later being signed into law by Vladimir Putin.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2020, the Russian parliament legalised a constitutional ban on <a href="/wiki/Recognition_of_same-sex_unions_in_Russia" title="Recognition of same-sex unions in Russia">same-sex marriage</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and in 2021 the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Justice (Russia)">Ministry of Justice</a> designated the LGBTQ rights group <a href="/wiki/Russian_LGBT_Network" title="Russian LGBT Network">Russian LGBT Network</a> as a "<a href="/wiki/Foreign_agent_(Russia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign agent (Russia)">foreign agent</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2022, further amendments were made to the 2013 anti-LGBTQ law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, the Russian parliament passed a bill banning <a href="/wiki/Gender_reassignment_surgery" class="mw-redirect" title="Gender reassignment surgery">gender reassignment surgery</a> for <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> people and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Russia" title="Supreme Court of Russia">Supreme Court of Russia</a> banned the <a href="/wiki/LGBTQ_movements" title="LGBTQ movements">international LGBTQ movement</a> as "extremist", outlawing it in the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, the Supreme Court issued the first convictions from the latter ruling.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Economy">Economy</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Russia" title="Economy of Russia">Economy of Russia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Economic history of the Russian Federation">Economic history of the Russian Federation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Russia" title="Taxation in Russia">Taxation in Russia</a></div>
<p>Russia has a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">high-income</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> industrialised,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed</a> <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market-oriented</a> economy following a <a href="/wiki/Shock_therapy_(economics)" title="Shock therapy (economics)">turbulent transition</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">Soviet planned model</a> during the 1990s.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998295382The&#95;Economy&#95;415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998295382The_Economy-415"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>, it has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">ninth-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">fourth-largest economy</a> by GDP (<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IMFWEO.RU&#95;16-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEO.RU-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a> accounts for roughly 57% of total GDP, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial sector">industrial sector</a> (30%), while the <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Agricultural sector">agricultural sector</a> is the smallest, at 3% of total GDP.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has a labour force of about 73 million, which is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_force" title="List of countries by labour force">eighth-largest</a> in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_largest_trading_partners_of_Russia" title="List of the largest trading partners of Russia">Russia's largest trading partner</a> is China.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oec&#95;420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oec-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow-City_2025.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Moscow-City_2025.jpg/250px-Moscow-City_2025.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="154" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Moscow-City_2025.jpg/500px-Moscow-City_2025.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1096" data-file-height="675" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">Moscow International Business Center</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/Human_development_(economics)" title="Human development (economics)">human development</a> is <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">ranked as</a> "very high" in the annual <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Roughly 70% of Russia's total GDP is driven by <a href="/wiki/Final_consumption_expenditure" title="Final consumption expenditure">final consumption</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the country has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_consumer_markets" title="List of largest consumer markets">twelfth-largest consumer market</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_billionaires" title="List of countries by number of billionaires">fifth-highest number of billionaires</a> in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, its <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by income equality">income inequality</a> remains comparatively high compared to other developed countries.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The variance of natural resources among its federal subjects has also led to <a href="/wiki/List_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_by_GDP_per_capita" title="List of federal subjects of Russia by GDP per capita">regional economic disparities</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> High <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">levels of corruption</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>418<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> declining oil export revenues,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> a shrinking labour force,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Human_capital_flight" title="Human capital flight">human capital flight</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and an <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_Russia" title="Aging of Russia">aging</a> and <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Russia" title="Demographics of Russia">declining population</a> also remain major barriers to future economic growth.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>422<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, the country has faced <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine">extensive sanctions</a> and other negative financial actions from the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western world</a> and its allies which have the aim of isolating the Russian economy from the Western financial system.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Walsh-2022&#95;217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walsh-2022-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Russia has completed its transition into a <a href="/wiki/War_economy" title="War economy">war economy</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and has shown resilience to such measures broadly, maintaining economic stability and growthdriven primarily by high <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_with_highest_military_expenditures" title="List of countries with highest military expenditures">military expenditure</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>425<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> rising <a href="/wiki/Household_final_consumption_expenditure" title="Household final consumption expenditure">household consumption</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_federal_subjects_by_average_wage" title="List of Russian federal subjects by average wage">wages</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>426<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> low <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">unemployment</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-reutersunem&#95;437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reutersunem-437"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>427<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and increased <a href="/wiki/Government_spending" title="Government spending">government spending</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Yet, <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> has remained comparatively high,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>429<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with experts predicting the sanctions will have a long-term negative effect on the Russian economy.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>430<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Transport_and_energy">Transport and energy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Russia" title="Transport in Russia">Transport in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Russia" title="Energy in Russia">Energy in Russia</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Russia" title="Rail transport in Russia">Railway transport in Russia</a> is mostly controlled by the state-run <a href="/wiki/Russian_Railways" title="Russian Railways">Russian Railways</a>. The total length of common-used railway tracks is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size" title="List of countries by rail transport network size">third-longest</a>, exceeding 87,000&#160;km (54,100&#160;mi).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Russia has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size" title="List of countries by road network size">fifth-largest road network</a>, with over 1.5 million&#160;km of roads.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, its road density is among the world's lowest, in part to its vast land area.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>433<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia's inland waterways are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_waterways_length" title="List of countries by waterways length">longest in the world</a>, totalling 102,000&#160;km (63,380&#160;mi).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>434<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has over <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Russia" title="List of airports in Russia">900 airports</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> ranking seventh in the world, of which the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Russia" title="List of the busiest airports in Russia">busiest</a> is <a href="/wiki/Sheremetyevo_International_Airport" title="Sheremetyevo International Airport">Sheremetyevo International Airport</a> in Moscow. The largest ports include the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Novorossiysk" title="Port of Novorossiysk">Port of Novorossiysk</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Port_of_Saint_Petersburg" title="Great Port of Saint Petersburg">Great Port of Saint Petersburg</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Vladivostok" title="Port of Vladivostok">Port of Vladivostok</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>436<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/250px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="143" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/330px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/VL_85-022_container_train.jpg/500px-VL_85-022_container_train.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1154" data-file-height="825" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;">The <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> is the longest railway line in the world, connecting Moscow to <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>437<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Airbus_A319-112,_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg/250px-Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg/330px-Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg/500px-Airbus_A319-112%2C_CSA_-_Czech_Airlines_AN2166020.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1158" data-file-height="846" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;"><a href="/wiki/Sheremetyevo_International_Airport" title="Sheremetyevo International Airport">Sheremetyevo International Airport</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Russia" title="List of the busiest airports in Russia">busiest airport in Russia</a></span>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russia has one of the world's largest amounts of <a href="/wiki/World_energy_resources" title="World energy resources">energy resources</a> throughout its vast landmass, particularly <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oil_and_gas_reserves_and_resource_quantification" title="Oil and gas reserves and resource quantification">oil</a>, which play a crucial role in its energy self-sufficiency and exports.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998295382The&#95;Economy&#95;415-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998295382The_Economy-415"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has been widely described <a href="/wiki/Russia_as_an_energy_superpower" class="mw-redirect" title="Russia as an energy superpower">as an energy superpower</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has the world's largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">proven gas reserves</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>439<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the second-largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_coal_reserves" title="List of countries by coal reserves">coal reserves</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>440<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the eighth-largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">proven oil reserves</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>441<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_shale_reserves" title="Oil shale reserves">oil shale reserves</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>442<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, it is also the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_production" title="List of countries by natural gas production">second-largest producer</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>443<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_exports" title="List of countries by natural gas exports">third-largest exporter</a> of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>444<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as well as the second-largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_production" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by oil production">producer</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">exporter</a> of <a href="/wiki/Crude_oil" class="mw-redirect" title="Crude oil">crude oil</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>445<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia's large oil and gas sector accounted for 30% of its federal budget revenues in 2024, down from 50% in the mid-2010s, suggesting economic diversification.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>446<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is the world's third-largest energy producer as of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>447<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">Fossil fuels</a> account for over 64% of energy production and 87% of energy consumption.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-energy&#95;458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Natural gas is by far the largest source of energy, comprising over half of the energy production and 42% of electricity consumption.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-energy&#95;458-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia was the first country to develop civilian nuclear power, building the world's <a href="/wiki/Obninsk_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant">first nuclear power plant</a> in 1954, and remains a pioneer in nuclear energy technology and is considered a world leader in <a href="/wiki/Fast-neutron_reactor" title="Fast-neutron reactor">fast neutron reactors</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:4&#95;459-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-459"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is the world's <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country" title="Nuclear power by country">fourth-largest nuclear energy producer</a>. Russian energy policy aims to expand the role of nuclear energy and develop new reactor technology.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:4&#95;459-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-459"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is the sole country that builds and operates <a href="/wiki/Nuclear-powered_icebreaker" title="Nuclear-powered icebreaker">nuclear-powered icebreakers</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-icebreaker&#95;460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-icebreaker-460"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which ease navigation along the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Sea_Route" title="Northern Sea Route">Northern Sea Route</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-icebreaker&#95;460-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-icebreaker-460"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 192">&#58;&#8202;192&#8202;</span></sup> and aid in utilising its <a href="/wiki/Arctic_policy_of_Russia" title="Arctic policy of Russia">Arctic policy</a> in its <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf_of_Russia" title="Continental shelf of Russia">continental shelf</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>451<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia joined the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a> on <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> in 2015, and ratified the agreement in 2019.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>452<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_Russia" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by Russia">Its greenhouse gas emissions</a> are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions">fourth-largest in the world</a> as of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>453<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Coal accounts for over 10% of its energy consumption.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-energy&#95;458-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is the <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity#World_hydroelectric_capacity" title="Hydroelectricity">fifth-largest hydroelectric producer</a> as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>454<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with hydroelectric power contributing almost a fifth to the total energy generation (17%).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-energy&#95;458-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Though it is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_renewable_electricity_production" title="List of countries by renewable electricity production">eighth-largest renewable energy producer</a> as of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the use and development of other <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> resources remain negligible,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-energy&#95;458-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-energy-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as Russia is among the few countries without strong governmental or public support for a <a href="/wiki/Energy_transition" title="Energy transition">renewable energy transition</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:5&#95;465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-465"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>455<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Agriculture_and_fishery">Agriculture and fishery</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Russia" title="Agriculture in Russia">Agriculture in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_in_Russia" title="Fishing industry in Russia">Fishing industry in Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Wheat_Tomsk.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wheat_Tomsk.jpg/250px-Wheat_Tomsk.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wheat_Tomsk.jpg/500px-Wheat_Tomsk.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a><figcaption>Wheat in <a href="/wiki/Tomsk_Oblast" title="Tomsk Oblast">Tomsk Oblast</a>, Siberia</figcaption></figure>
<p>Agriculture, <a href="/wiki/Forestry_in_Russia" title="Forestry in Russia">forestry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_in_Russia" title="Fishing industry in Russia">fishing</a> contributes about 3.3% of the country's total GDP as of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>456<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has the world's <a href="/wiki/Land_use_statistics_by_country" title="Land use statistics by country">fourth-largest cultivated area</a>, at 1,265,267 square kilometres (488,522&#160;sq&#160;mi). However, due to the harshness of its environment, only about 13.1% of its land is <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_land" title="Agricultural land">agricultural</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with an additional 7.4% being <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>457<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country's agricultural land is considered part of the "<a href="/wiki/Breadbasket" title="Breadbasket">breadbasket</a>" of Europe.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>458<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> More than one-third of the sown area is devoted to fodder crops, and the remaining farmland is used <a href="/wiki/Nonfood_crop" title="Nonfood crop">industrial crops</a>, vegetables, and fruits.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-agriculturebritannica&#95;469-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-469"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>459<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The main product of Russian farming has always been grain, which occupies well over half the cropland.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-agriculturebritannica&#95;469-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-469"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>459<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_wheat_exports" title="List of countries by wheat exports">largest exporter of wheat</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_barley_production" title="List of countries by barley production">largest producer of barley</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_producing_countries_of_agricultural_commodities" title="List of largest producing countries of agricultural commodities">buckwheat</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oec&#95;420-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oec-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-fao&#95;470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao-470"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>460<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is also among the largest exporters of <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_oil" title="Sunflower oil">sunflower oil</a>, as well as the leading producer of <a href="/wiki/Fertilizer" title="Fertilizer">fertiliser</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-fao&#95;470-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao-470"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>460<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-oec&#95;420-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oec-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Various analysts of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_adaptation" title="Climate change adaptation">climate change adaptation</a> foresee large opportunities for Russian agriculture during the rest of the 21st century as arability increases in Siberia, which would lead to both internal and external migration to the region.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>461<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Owing to its large coastline along three oceans and twelve marginal seas, Russia maintains the world's <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_by_country" title="Fishing industry by country">sixth-largest fishing industry</a>, capturing nearly 5 million tons of fish in 2018.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>462<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is home to the world's finest caviar, the <a href="/wiki/Beluga_(sturgeon)" title="Beluga (sturgeon)">beluga</a>, and produces about one-third of all canned fish and some one-fourth of the world's total fresh and frozen fish.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-agriculturebritannica&#95;469-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agriculturebritannica-469"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>459<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Russia" title="Science and technology in Russia">Science and technology in Russia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_innovation" title="Timeline of Russian innovation">Timeline of Russian innovation</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_scientists" title="List of Russian scientists">List of Russian scientists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_inventors" title="List of Russian inventors">List of Russian inventors</a></div>
<p>Russia spent about 1% of its GDP on <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> in 2019, with the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by research and development spending">tenth-highest budget</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>463<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It also ranked tenth worldwide in the number of scientific publications in 2020, with roughly 1.3 million papers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>464<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 1904, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">Nobel Prize</a> were awarded to 26 Soviets and Russians in <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_medicine" class="mw-redirect" title="Nobel Prize in medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Memorial_Prize_in_Economic_Sciences" title="Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences">economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">peace</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>465<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia ranked 60th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2025.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>466<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>467<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>468<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since the times of <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Lobachevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Lobachevsky">Nikolay Lobachevsky</a>, who pioneered the <a href="/wiki/Non-Euclidean_geometry" title="Non-Euclidean geometry">non-Euclidean geometry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pafnuty_Chebyshev" title="Pafnuty Chebyshev">Pafnuty Chebyshev</a>, a prominent tutor, Russian <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_mathematicians" title="List of Russian mathematicians">mathematicians</a> became among the world's most influential.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-math&#95;479-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-math-479"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Mendeleev" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitry Mendeleev">Dmitry Mendeleev</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table" title="Periodic table">Periodic table</a>, the main framework of modern <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>470<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Nine Soviet and Russian mathematicians have been awarded with the <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal_winners" class="mw-redirect" title="Fields Medal winners">Fields Medal</a>. <a href="/wiki/Grigori_Perelman" title="Grigori Perelman">Grigori Perelman</a> was offered the first ever Clay <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Prize_Problems" title="Millennium Prize Problems">Millennium Prize Problems</a> Award for his final proof of the <a href="/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture" title="Poincar conjecture">Poincar conjecture</a> in 2002, as well as the Fields Medal in 2006.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>471<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/250px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="255" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/330px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/500px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="597" data-file-height="800" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> (17111765), <a href="/wiki/Polymath" title="Polymath">polymath</a> scientist, inventor, poet and artist</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Alexander_Stepanovich_Popov" class="mw-redirect" title="Alexander Stepanovich Popov">Alexander Popov</a> was among the <a href="/wiki/Invention_of_radio" title="Invention of radio">inventors of radio</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Basov" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolai Basov">Nikolai Basov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Prokhorov" title="Alexander Prokhorov">Alexander Prokhorov</a> were co-inventors of <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">laser</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maser" title="Maser">maser</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>473<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Oleg_Losev" title="Oleg Losev">Oleg Losev</a> made crucial contributions in the field of <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor_junction" class="mw-redirect" title="Semiconductor junction">semiconductor junctions</a>, and discovered <a href="/wiki/Light-emitting_diode" title="Light-emitting diode">light-emitting diodes</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>474<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vernadsky" title="Vladimir Vernadsky">Vladimir Vernadsky</a> is considered one of the founders of <a href="/wiki/Geochemistry" title="Geochemistry">geochemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biogeochemistry" title="Biogeochemistry">biogeochemistry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating">radiogeology</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>475<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lie_Metchnikoff" title="lie Metchnikoff">lie Metchnikoff</a> is known for his groundbreaking research in <a href="/wiki/Immunology" title="Immunology">immunology</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>476<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Pavlov" title="Ivan Pavlov">Ivan Pavlov</a> is known chiefly for his work in <a href="/wiki/Classical_conditioning" title="Classical conditioning">classical conditioning</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>477<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lev_Landau" title="Lev Landau">Lev Landau</a> made fundamental contributions to many areas of <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>478<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Vavilov" title="Nikolai Vavilov">Nikolai Vavilov</a> was best known for having identified the <a href="/wiki/Vavilov_center" title="Vavilov center">centres</a> of origin of <a href="/wiki/Horticulture" title="Horticulture">cultivated</a> plants.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>479<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Trofim_Lysenko" title="Trofim Lysenko">Trofim Lysenko</a> was known mainly for <a href="/wiki/Lysenkoism" title="Lysenkoism">Lysenkoism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>480<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Many famous Russian scientists and inventors were <a href="/wiki/%C3%89migr%C3%A9s" class="mw-redirect" title="migrs">migrs</a>. <a href="/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky" title="Igor Sikorsky">Igor Sikorsky</a> was an <a href="/wiki/List_of_aviation_pioneers" title="List of aviation pioneers">aviation pioneer</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>481<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Zworykin" class="mw-redirect" title="Vladimir Zworykin">Vladimir Zworykin</a> was the inventor of the <a href="/wiki/Iconoscope" title="Iconoscope">iconoscope</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kinescope" title="Kinescope">kinescope</a> television systems.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>482<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_Dobzhansky" title="Theodosius Dobzhansky">Theodosius Dobzhansky</a> was the central figure in the field of <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_biology" title="Evolutionary biology">evolutionary biology</a> for his work in shaping the <a href="/wiki/Modern_synthesis_(20th_century)" title="Modern synthesis (20th century)">modern synthesis</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>483<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/George_Gamow" title="George Gamow">George Gamow</a> was one of the foremost advocates of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bang" title="Big Bang">Big Bang</a> theory.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>484<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Space_exploration">Space exploration</h4></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/250px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="239" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/500px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="2010" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a>, Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> that operated in <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">LEO</a></figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Roscosmos" title="Roscosmos">Roscosmos</a> is Russia's national space agency. The country's achievements in the field of <a href="/wiki/Space_technology" title="Space technology">space technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> can be traced back to <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Tsiolkovsky" title="Konstantin Tsiolkovsky">Konstantin Tsiolkovsky</a>, the father of theoretical <a href="/wiki/Astronautics" title="Astronautics">astronautics</a>, whose works had inspired leading Soviet rocket engineers, such as <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Korolyov" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Korolyov">Sergey Korolyov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valentin_Glushko" title="Valentin Glushko">Valentin Glushko</a>, and many others who contributed to the success of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet space programme</a> in the early stages of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a> and beyond.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>485<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 67, 333">&#58;&#8202;67,&#8202;333&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>In 1957, the first Earth-orbiting artificial <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">Sputnik&#160;1</a></i>, was launched. In 1961, the first human trip into space was successfully made by <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a>. Many other Soviet and Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Space exploration records">space exploration records</a> ensued. In 1963, <a href="/wiki/Valentina_Tereshkova" title="Valentina Tereshkova">Valentina Tereshkova</a> became the first and youngest <a href="/wiki/Women_in_space" title="Women in space">woman in space</a>, having flown a solo mission on <a href="/wiki/Vostok_6" title="Vostok 6">Vostok 6</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>486<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1965, <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Leonov" title="Alexei Leonov">Alexei Leonov</a> became the first human to conduct a <a href="/wiki/Spacewalk" class="mw-redirect" title="Spacewalk">spacewalk</a>, exiting the <a href="/wiki/Space_capsule" title="Space capsule">space capsule</a> during <a href="/wiki/Voskhod_2" title="Voskhod 2">Voskhod 2</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>487<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 1957, <a href="/wiki/Laika" title="Laika">Laika</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_dogs" title="Soviet space dogs">Soviet space dog</a>, became the first animal to orbit the Earth, aboard <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_2" title="Sputnik 2">Sputnik 2</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>488<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1966, <a href="/wiki/Luna_9" title="Luna 9">Luna&#160;9</a> became the first spacecraft to achieve a survivable landing on a <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_object" title="Astronomical object">celestial body</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-499" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-499"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>489<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1968, <a href="/wiki/Zond_5" title="Zond 5">Zond 5</a> brought the first Earthlings (two tortoises and other life forms) to circumnavigate the Moon.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-500" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>490<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1970, <a href="/wiki/Venera_7" title="Venera 7">Venera&#160;7</a> became the first spacecraft to land on another planet, <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>491<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1971, <a href="/wiki/Mars_3" title="Mars 3">Mars&#160;3</a> became the first spacecraft to land on <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>492<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 3460">&#58;&#8202;3460&#8202;</span></sup> During the same period, <i><a href="/wiki/Lunokhod-1" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunokhod-1">Lunokhod 1</a></i> became the first <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration_rover" class="mw-redirect" title="Space exploration rover">space exploration rover</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>493<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while <i><a href="/wiki/Salyut_1" title="Salyut 1">Salyut&#160;1</a></i> became the world's first <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>494<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Russia has 181 active satellites in space, which is the third-highest in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>495<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Between the final flight of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a> programme in 2011 and the 2020 <a href="/wiki/SpaceX" title="SpaceX">SpaceX</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Crew_Dragon_Demo-2" title="Crew Dragon Demo-2">first crewed mission</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soyuz_(rocket_family)" title="Soyuz (rocket family)">Soyuz rockets</a> were the only launch vehicles capable of transporting astronauts to the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">ISS</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>496<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Luna_25" title="Luna 25">Luna&#160;25</a> launched in August 2023, was the first of the <a href="/wiki/Luna-Glob" title="Luna-Glob">Luna-Glob</a> Moon exploration programme.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>497<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tourism">Tourism</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Russia" title="Tourism in Russia">Tourism in Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Peterhof_Palace,_Saint_Petersburg,_Russia_(44408938295).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Peterhof_Palace%2C_Saint_Petersburg%2C_Russia_%2844408938295%29.jpg/250px-Peterhof_Palace%2C_Saint_Petersburg%2C_Russia_%2844408938295%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Peterhof_Palace%2C_Saint_Petersburg%2C_Russia_%2844408938295%29.jpg/500px-Peterhof_Palace%2C_Saint_Petersburg%2C_Russia_%2844408938295%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3202" data-file-height="1873" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof Palace</a> in Saint Petersburg, a UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Most foreign tourists come from China.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>498<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Major tourist routes in Russia include a journey around the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Ring_of_Russia" title="Golden Ring of Russia">Golden Ring of Russia</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Theme_route" class="mw-redirect" title="Theme route">theme route</a> of ancient Russian cities; cruises on large rivers such as the Volga; hikes on mountain ranges such as the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus Mountains</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>499<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and journeys on the famous <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>500<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia's most visited and popular landmarks include <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof Palace</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Kremlin" title="Kazan Kremlin">Kazan Kremlin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Lavra_of_St._Sergius" title="Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius">Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius</a> and Lake Baikal.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>501<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Moscow, the nation's cosmopolitan capital and historic core, is a bustling modern <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a>; it retains classical and Soviet-era architecture while boasting high art, world class ballet, and <a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">modern skyscrapers</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>502<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, the imperial capital, is famous for its classical architecture, cathedrals, museums and theatres, <a href="/wiki/White_Nights_Festival" title="White Nights Festival">white nights</a>, crisscrossing rivers and numerous canals.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>503<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is famed worldwide for its rich museums, such as the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Museum" title="Russian Museum">State Russian</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hermitage_Museum" title="Hermitage Museum">State Hermitage</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Tretyakov_Gallery" title="Tretyakov Gallery">Tretyakov Gallery</a>, and for theatres such as the <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre" title="Bolshoi Theatre">Bolshoi</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mariinsky_Theatre" title="Mariinsky Theatre">Mariinsky</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin" class="mw-redirect" title="Moscow Kremlin">Moscow Kremlin</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a> are among the cultural landmarks of Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>504<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Demographics">Demographics</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Russia" title="Demographics of Russia">Demographics of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia" title="List of cities and towns in Russia">List of cities and towns in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia_by_population" title="List of cities and towns in Russia by population">List of cities and towns in Russia by population</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png/250px-Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="132" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png/330px-Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png/500px-Russia_Population_Density_Map_2021.png 2x" data-file-width="6441" data-file-height="4263" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Population density of Russian municipalities according to the 2021 census</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/250px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="117" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/330px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/500px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png 2x" data-file-width="4836" data-file-height="2820" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;">Ethnic groups in Russia with a population of over one million according to the 2010 census</span></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russia had an estimated population of 146.0 million in 2025 (143.6 million excluding Crimea and Sevastopol),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-gks.ru-popul&#95;15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks.ru-popul-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> down from 147.2 million in the <a href="/wiki/2021_Russian_census" title="2021 Russian census">2021 census</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-2021census&#95;515-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2021census-515"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>505<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">most populous country</a> in Europe and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">ninth-most populous country</a> in the world. With a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population density">population density</a> of 8.5 inhabitants&#160;per square kilometre (22 inhabitants/mi<sup>2</sup>),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>506<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population_density" title="List of countries and dependencies by population density">most sparsely populated</a> countries,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with the vast majority of its people concentrated within its <a href="/wiki/European_Russia" title="European Russia">western part</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998153166Population&#95;517-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998153166Population-517"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>507<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country is <a href="/wiki/Urbanization_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Urbanization by country">highly urbanised</a>, with two-thirds of the population living in <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia_by_population" title="List of cities and towns in Russia by population">urban areas</a>. As of 2024<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> across Russia is estimated to be 1.41 children born per woman,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>508<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which is below the <a href="/wiki/Replacement_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Replacement rate">replacement rate</a> of 2.1 and among <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependencies_by_total_fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereign states and dependencies by total fertility rate">the lowest in the world</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-519" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-519"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>509<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Subsequently, it has one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_median_age" title="List of countries by median age">oldest populations</a> in the world, with a median age of 41.9 years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
