</p><p>Russia's population peaked at over 148 million in 1993, having subsequently declined due to its <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rate">death rate</a> exceeding its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>, which some analysts have called a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_crisis_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Demographic crisis of Russia">demographic crisis</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-520" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-520"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>510<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2009, it recorded annual population growth for the first time in fifteen years, and subsequently experienced annual population growth due to declining <a href="/wiki/Death_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rates">death rates</a>, increased <a href="/wiki/Birth_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Birth rates">birth rates</a>, and increased immigration.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-521" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-521"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>511<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, these population gains have been reversed since 2020, as excessive deaths from the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Russia" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Russia">COVID-19 pandemic</a> resulted in the largest peacetime decline in its history.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>512<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, the demographic crisis has deepened,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>513<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> owing to high military fatalities<sup id="cite&#95;ref-524" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-524"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>514<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_emigration_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian emigration during the Russian invasion of Ukraine">renewed emigration</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-525" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-525"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>515<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Recent studies have shown that between 15-45% of Russian emigrants have returned to Russia, though these numbers are not conclusive.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-526" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-526"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>516<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Multinational_state" title="Multinational state">multinational state</a> with many subnational entities associated with different minorities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998172201Ethnic&#95;Composition&#95;527-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998172201Ethnic_Composition-527"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>517<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are over <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia" title="Ethnic groups in Russia">193 ethnic groups nationwide</a>. In the 2010 census, roughly 81% of the population were ethnic <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>, and the remaining 19% of the population were ethnic minorities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>518<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Over four-fifths of Russia's population was of <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic groups of Europe">European descent</a>of whom the vast majority were <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavs</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998172201Ethnic&#95;Composition&#95;527-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998172201Ethnic_Composition-527"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>517<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>519<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with a substantial minority of <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Finno-Ugric peoples">Finno-Ugric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic peoples</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-530" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-530"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>520<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-531" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-531"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>521<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has the third-largest <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Russia" title="Immigration to Russia">immigrant population</a> in the world, with over 12 million immigrants residing in the country as of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-532" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-532"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>522<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The vast majority of the Immigrants hail from <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a>, with about half of them being from <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Russia" title="Ukrainians in Russia">Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazakhs_in_Russia" title="Kazakhs in Russia">Kazakhstan</a> as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>523<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1219497266">.mw-parser-output .largestCities-table-background{background:#f9f9f9;color:#222}.mw-parser-output .largestCities-cell-background{background:#f0f0f0;color:#222}</style>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray;">

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Language">Language</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Russia" title="Languages of Russia">Languages of Russia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Minority languages across Russia</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:135px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic,_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_(en).png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/250px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png" decoding="async" width="215" height="135" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/330px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/500px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 2x" data-file-width="3245" data-file-height="2036" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Altaic_languages" title="Altaic languages">Altaic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic languages</a> spoken across Russia</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:121px;max-width:121px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:135px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/120px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="119" height="135" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/250px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="977" data-file-height="1111" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">The <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a> is <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" class="mw-redirect" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">ethno</a>-<a href="/wiki/North_Caucasian_languages" title="North Caucasian languages">linguistically</a> diverse.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-535" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-535"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>525<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russian is the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official</a> and the predominantly spoken language in Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Chevalier-2006&#95;4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chevalier-2006-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is the most spoken <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">native language</a> in Europe, the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the world's most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">Slavic language</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-language&#95;536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-language-536"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>526<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russian is one of two official languages aboard the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-537" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-537"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>527<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as well as one of the six <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations" title="Official languages of the United Nations">official languages of the United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-language&#95;536-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-language-536"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>526<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Multilingualism#Europe" title="Multilingualism">multilingual</a> nation: approximately 100150 minority languages are spoken across the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>528<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-539" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-539"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>529<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Census_(2010)" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Census (2010)">Russian Census of 2010</a>, 137.5&#160;million across the country spoke Russian, 3.1&#160;million spoke <a href="/wiki/Tatar_language" title="Tatar language">Tatar</a>, and 1.1&#160;million spoke <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>530<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The constitution gives the country's individual republics the right to <a href="/wiki/List_of_official_languages_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of official languages in Russia">establish their own state languages</a> in addition to Russian, as well as guarantee its citizens the right to preserve their native language and to create conditions for its study and development.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>531<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, various experts have claimed Russia's linguistic diversity is rapidly declining due to <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_Russia" title="List of endangered languages in Russia">many languages becoming endangered</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-542" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-542"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>532<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>533<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Religion">Religion</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Russia" title="Religion in Russia">Religion in Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg/250px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg/500px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%8C_%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%8F%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D1%8B._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Trinity_Sunday" title="Trinity Sunday">Trinity Sunday</a> in Russia; the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> has experienced a great revival since the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, a country that had a policy of <a href="/wiki/State_atheism" title="State atheism">state atheism</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Russia is constitutionally a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> that officially enshrines freedom of religion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998202220Religion&#95;544-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998202220Religion-544"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>534<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;545-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-545"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>535<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The largest religion is <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox Christianity">Eastern Orthodox Christianity</a>, chiefly represented by the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998202220Religion&#95;544-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998202220Religion-544"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>534<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArenaAtlas2012&#95;546-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-546"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>536<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which is legally recognised for its "special role" in the country's "history and the formation and development of its spirituality and culture."<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;545-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-545"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>535<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> are recognised by Russian law as the "traditional" religions of the country constituting its "historical heritage".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>537<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>538<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Islam is the second-largest religion in Russia and is traditional among the majority of <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" class="mw-redirect" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">peoples in the North Caucasus</a> and some <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic peoples</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Idel-Ural" title="Idel-Ural">Volga-Ural</a> region.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998202220Religion&#95;544-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998202220Religion-544"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>534<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArenaAtlas2012&#95;546-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-546"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>536<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Large populations of Buddhists are found in <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buryatia" title="Buryatia">Buryatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zabaykalsky_Krai" title="Zabaykalsky Krai">Zabaykalsky Krai</a>, and they are the vast majority of the population in <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArenaAtlas2012&#95;546-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-546"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>536<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A negligible population practices other religionssuch as <a href="/wiki/Rodnovery" class="mw-redirect" title="Rodnovery">Rodnovery</a> (Slavic Neopaganism),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>539<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Assianism" title="Assianism">Assianism</a> (Scythian Neopaganism),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>540<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> other ethnic Paganisms, and inter-Pagan movements such as <a href="/wiki/Ringing_Cedars%27_Anastasianism" title="Ringing Cedars&#39; Anastasianism">Ringing Cedars' Anastasianism</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-551" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-551"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>541<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> various movements of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>542<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Siberian_shamanism" class="mw-redirect" title="Siberian shamanism">Siberian shamanism</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>543<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tengrism" title="Tengrism">Tengrism</a>, various <a href="/wiki/Neo-Theosophy" title="Neo-Theosophy">Neo-Theosophical</a> movements such as <a href="/wiki/Roerichism" title="Roerichism">Roerichism</a>among other faiths.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>544<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>545<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some religious minorities have faced oppression and some have been banned in the country:<sup id="cite&#95;ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>546<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> notably, in 2017 the <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah&#39;s Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> were outlawed in Russia, facing persecution ever since, after having been declared an "extremist" and "nontraditional" faith.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>547<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, the research organisation Sreda, in cooperation with the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Justice (Russia)">Ministry of Justice</a>, published the Arena Atlas, an adjunct to the 2010 census, enumerating in detail the religious populations and nationalities of Russia, based on a large-sample country-wide survey. The results showed that 47.3% of Russians declared themselves Christiansincluding 41% Russian Orthodox, 1.5% simply Orthodox or members of non-Russian Orthodox churches, 4.1% unaffiliated Christians, and less than 1% <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">Old Believers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholics</a> or <a href="/wiki/Protestants" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestants">Protestants</a>25% were <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_but_not_religious" title="Spiritual but not religious">believers without affiliation to any specific religion</a>, 13% were <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a>, 6.5% were Muslims,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArenaAtlasIslam&#95;558-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlasIslam-558"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>k<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 1.2% were followers of "traditional religions honouring gods and ancestors" (<a href="/wiki/Slavic_Native_Faith" title="Slavic Native Faith">Rodnovery</a>, other Paganisms, <a href="/wiki/Shamanism_in_Siberia" title="Shamanism in Siberia">Siberian shamanism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tengrism" title="Tengrism">Tengrism</a>), 0.5% were Buddhists, 0.1% were <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">religious Jews</a> and 0.1% were Hindus.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArenaAtlas2012&#95;546-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-546"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>536<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Education">Education</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">Education in Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3,_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/250px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg/500px-%D0%9C%D0%93%D0%A3%2C_%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B4_%D1%81_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B4%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3946" data-file-height="2610" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a>, the most prestigious educational institution in Russia<sup id="cite&#95;ref-559" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-559"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>548<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Russia has a near-universal adult <a href="/wiki/Literate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literate">literacy rate</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-560" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-560"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>549<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and has <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> for a duration of 11 years, exclusively for children aged 7 to 1718.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Nuffic-2019&#95;561-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nuffic-2019-561"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>550<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It grants <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">free education</a> to its citizens by constitution.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CEPES&#95;562-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CEPES-562"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>551<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Education (Russia)">Ministry of Education of Russia</a> is responsible for primary and secondary education, as well as vocational education, while the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Science_and_Higher_Education_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Science and Higher Education (Russia)">Ministry of Education and Science of Russia</a> is responsible for science and higher education.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Nuffic-2019&#95;561-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nuffic-2019-561"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>550<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Regional authorities regulate education within their jurisdictions within the prevailing framework of federal laws. As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, over 41% of the Russian population has a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor&#39;s degree">bachelor's degree</a> or an equivalentwhich is among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tertiary_education_attainment" title="List of countries by tertiary education attainment">highest percentages</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary-level graduates</a> in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-563" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-563"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>552<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/Pre-school" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-school">pre-school</a> education system is highly developed and optional,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-564" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-564"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>553<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> some four-fifths of children aged 3 to 6 attend day nurseries or kindergartens. Primary school is compulsory for eleven years, starting from age 6 to 7, and leads to a basic general education certificate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Nuffic-2019&#95;561-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nuffic-2019-561"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>550<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An additional two or three years of schooling are required for the secondary-level certificate, and some seven-eighths of Russians continue their education past this level.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Educationb&#95;565-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Educationb-565"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>554<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Admission to an institute of higher education is selective and highly competitive:<sup id="cite&#95;ref-566" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-566"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>555<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> first-degree courses usually take five years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Educationb&#95;565-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Educationb-565"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>554<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The oldest and largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_institutions_of_higher_education_in_Russia" title="List of institutions of higher education in Russia">universities</a> in Russia are <a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_State_University" title="Saint Petersburg State University">Saint Petersburg State University</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-567" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-567"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>556<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There are ten <a href="/wiki/Template:Federal_universities_of_Russia" title="Template:Federal universities of Russia">federal universities</a> across the country.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health">Health</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Russia" title="Health in Russia">Health in Russia</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">Healthcare in Russia</a></div>
<p>Russia constitutionally guarantees free, <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> for all Russian citizens through the <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance_mandate" title="Health insurance mandate">mandatory medical insurance</a> (OMS) funded by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Compulsory_Medical_Insurance_Fund_(Russia)" title="Federal Compulsory Medical Insurance Fund (Russia)">Federal Compulsory Medical Insurance Fund</a> (FFOMS) created in 1993.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>557<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECDhealth&#95;569-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDhealth-569"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>558<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-thompson&#95;570-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thompson-570"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>559<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Health (Russia)">Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation</a> oversees national <a href="/wiki/Health_care" title="Health care">healthcare</a>. Its healthcare system has decentralized since the 1990s, with federal entities having local healthcare departments, shifting from the centralized and hierarchical Soviet system.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-OECDhealth&#95;569-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDhealth-569"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>558<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Private healthcare has also seen development, created out of the <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">public healthcare fund</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-571" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-571"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>560<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-thompson&#95;570-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thompson-570"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>559<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Metallurg_Sochi.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Metallurg_Sochi.jpg/250px-Metallurg_Sochi.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Metallurg_Sochi.jpg/500px-Metallurg_Sochi.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744" /></a><figcaption>Metallurg, a Soviet-era <a href="/wiki/Sanatorium" title="Sanatorium">sanatorium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-572" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-572"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>561<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>Russia spent 7.39% of its GDP on healthcare in 2021.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-573" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-573"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>562<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its healthcare expenditure is notably lower than other developed nations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-574" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-574"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>563<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the overall <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy in Russia</a> at birth is 73 years,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>564<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> an increase of roughly 8 years from 2005.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>565<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">highest gender gaps in life expectancy</a>78 for females and 68 for malesa gap of 10 years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-men&#95;577-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-men-577"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>566<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-578" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-578"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>567<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-579" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-579"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>568<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has one of the most female-biased <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">sex ratios</a> in the world, with 0.859 males to every female,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia&#95;7-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> due to its high male <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-men&#95;577-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-men-577"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>566<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-su&#95;580-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-su-580"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>569<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-thompson&#95;570-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thompson-570"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>559<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia's <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality rate</a> is very low (4 per 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Live_birth_(human)" title="Live birth (human)">live births</a>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-581" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-581"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>570<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">Cardiovascular diseases</a> account for more than half of the yearly mortalities in Russia,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-582" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-582"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>571<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which is one of the highest percentages in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-583" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-583"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>572<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_in_Russia" title="Alcohol in Russia">alcohol consumption rate</a> was historically seen as the biggest health issue,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-584" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-584"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>573<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> but has seen <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_alcohol_consumption_per_capita" title="List of countries by alcohol consumption per capita">a stark decrease since 2008</a> due to restrictive government measures.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-585" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-585"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>574<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-586" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-586"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>575<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>576<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">Obesity</a> is a prevalent health issue, with most adults being overweight or obese,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-588" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-588"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>577<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> alongside <a href="/wiki/Smoking_in_Russia" title="Smoking in Russia">smoking</a>Russia's tobacco consumption rate is among the <a href="/wiki/Prevalence_of_tobacco_use" title="Prevalence of tobacco use">highest in the world</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-589" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-589"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>578<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_suicide_rate" title="List of countries by suicide rate">high suicide rate</a> also remains a <a href="/wiki/Suicide_in_Russia" title="Suicide in Russia">significant social issue</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>579<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-su&#95;580-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-su-580"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>569<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Culture">Culture</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian culture">Russian culture</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg/250px-Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="208" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg/500px-Moscow-Bolshoi-Theare-1.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="6728" data-file-height="5598" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre" title="Bolshoi Theatre">Bolshoi Theatre</a> in Moscow, at night</figcaption></figure>
<p>Russian culture reflects a long, gradual, and complex amalgamation of various elements that coincided with centuries of development, expansion, and interaction with different peoples, artistic movements, and cultures.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>580<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has heavily influenced <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical music</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998228230Music&#95;592-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998228230Music-592"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>581<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-593" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-593"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>582<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_ballet" title="Russian ballet">ballet</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998230232Ballet&#95;594-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998230232Ballet-594"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>583<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>584<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> theatre,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-596" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-596"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>585<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_mathematicians" title="List of Russian mathematicians">mathematics</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-math&#95;479-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-math-479"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Russia" title="Sport in Russia">sport</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Riordan-1993&#95;597-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Riordan-1993-597"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>586<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_artists" title="List of Russian artists">painting</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-599" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-599"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>588<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Russia" title="Cinema of Russia">cinema</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bulgakova-2012&#95;600-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bulgakova-2012-600"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>589<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian writers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" title="Russian philosophy">philosophers</a> have played an important role in the development of <a href="/wiki/Western_literature" title="Western literature">European literature</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-McLean-1962&#95;602-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McLean-1962-602"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>591<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and thought.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-603" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-603"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>592<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia also made pioneering <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_inventions_and_technology_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records">contributions to science, technology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-604" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-604"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>593<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-605" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-605"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>594<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is home to <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Russia" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Russia">32</a> UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites">World Heritage Sites</a>, 21 of which are cultural, while 31 lie on the tentative list.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-606" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-606"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>595<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The large global <a href="/wiki/Russian_diaspora" title="Russian diaspora">Russian diaspora</a> has also played a major role in spreading Russian culture throughout the world. Russia's national symbol, the <a href="/wiki/Double-headed_eagle" title="Double-headed eagle">double-headed eagle</a>, dates back to the Tsardom period and is featured in <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Russia" title="Coat of arms of Russia">its coat of arms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_heraldry" title="Russian heraldry">heraldry</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998Chapter&#95;12.&#95;Historical&#95;Setting&#95;63-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998Chapter_12._Historical_Setting-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Bear" title="Russian Bear">Russian Bear</a> and <a href="/wiki/Personification_of_Russia" title="Personification of Russia">Mother Russia</a> are often used as <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personifications</a> of the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-607" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-607"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>596<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-608" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-608"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>597<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Matryoshka_dolls" class="mw-redirect" title="Matryoshka dolls">Matryoshka dolls</a> are a cultural icon of Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>598<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Holidays">Holidays</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Russia" title="Public holidays in Russia">Public holidays in Russia</a></div>
<p>Russia has eight official holidays spanning public, patriotic, and religious commemorations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-610" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-610"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>599<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The year starts with New Year's Day on 1 January, soon followed by <a href="/wiki/Christmas_in_Russia" title="Christmas in Russia">Russian Orthodox Christmas</a> on 7 January; the two are the country's most popular holidays.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-611" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-611"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>600<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Defender_of_the_Fatherland_Day" title="Defender of the Fatherland Day">Defender of the Fatherland Day</a>, dedicated to men, is celebrated on 23 February.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-612" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-612"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>601<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day" title="International Women&#39;s Day">International Women's Day</a> on 8 March, gained momentum in Russia during the Soviet era. The annual celebration of women has become so popular, especially among Russian men, that the flower vendors of Moscow often see profits "fifteen times" more compared to other holidays.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-613" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-613"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>602<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/May_Day#Russia" title="May Day">Spring and Labour Day</a>, originally a Soviet era holiday dedicated to workers, is celebrated on 1 May.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-614" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-614"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>603<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg/250px-%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg/500px-%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8B%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_Sails_(tradition)" title="Scarlet Sails (tradition)">Scarlet Sails</a> being celebrated along the <a href="/wiki/Neva" title="Neva">Neva</a> in Saint Petersburg</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(Russia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Victory Day (Russia)">Victory Day</a>, which honours Soviet victory over Nazi Germany and the <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Europe" title="End of World War II in Europe">End of World War II in Europe</a>, is celebrated on 9 May as an annual <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Victory_Day_Parade" title="Moscow Victory Day Parade">large parade</a> in Moscow's Red Square<sup id="cite&#95;ref-615" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-615"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>604<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and marks the famous <a href="/wiki/Immortal_Regiment" title="Immortal Regiment">Immortal Regiment</a> civil event.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-616" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-616"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>605<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other patriotic holidays include <a href="/wiki/Russia_Day" title="Russia Day">Russia Day</a> on 12 June, celebrated to commemorate Russia's <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_State_Sovereignty_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Declaration of State Sovereignty of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">declaration of sovereignty</a> from the collapsing Soviet Union,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-617" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-617"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>606<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Unity_Day_(Russia)" title="Unity Day (Russia)">Unity Day</a> on 4 November, commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow_(1612)" title="Battle of Moscow (1612)">1612 uprising</a> that marked the end of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Russian_War_(1609%E2%80%931618)" title="PolishRussian War (16091618)">Polish occupation of Moscow</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-618" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-618"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>607<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>There are many popular non-public holidays. <a href="/wiki/Old_New_Year" title="Old New Year">Old New Year</a> is celebrated on 14 January.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-619" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-619"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>608<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maslenitsa" title="Maslenitsa">Maslenitsa</a> is an ancient and popular East Slavic folk holiday.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>609<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cosmonautics_Day" title="Cosmonautics Day">Cosmonautics Day</a> on 12 April, in tribute to the first human trip into space.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-621" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-621"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>610<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Two major Christian holidays are Easter and <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Sunday" title="Trinity Sunday">Trinity Sunday</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-622" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-622"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>611<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Art_and_architecture">Art and architecture</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_artists" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian artists">Russian artists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Russia" title="Architecture of Russia">Architecture of Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_architects" title="List of Russian architects">List of Russian architects</a></div>
<p>Early Russian painting is <a href="/wiki/Russian_icons" title="Russian icons">represented in icons</a> and vibrant <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">frescos</a>. In the early 15th century, master icon painter <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Rublev" title="Andrei Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a> created some of Russia's most treasured religious art.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Arts" title="Russian Academy of Arts">Russian Academy of Arts</a>, which was established in 1757 to train Russian artists, brought Western techniques of secular painting to Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998Chapter&#95;12.&#95;Historical&#95;Setting&#95;63-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998Chapter_12._Historical_Setting-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 18th century, academicians <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Argunov" title="Ivan Argunov">Ivan Argunov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Levitzky" title="Dmitry Levitzky">Dmitry Levitzky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Borovikovsky" title="Vladimir Borovikovsky">Vladimir Borovikovsky</a> became influential.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-623" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-623"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>612<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The early 19th century saw many prominent paintings by <a href="/wiki/Karl_Briullov" class="mw-redirect" title="Karl Briullov">Karl Briullov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Andreyevich_Ivanov" title="Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov">Alexander Ivanov</a>, both of whom were known for <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantic</a> historical canvases.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-624" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-624"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>613<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-625" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-625"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>614<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Aivazovsky" title="Ivan Aivazovsky">Ivan Aivazovsky</a>, another Romantic painter, is considered one of the greatest masters of <a href="/wiki/Marine_art" title="Marine art">marine art</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-626" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-626"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>615<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" data-file-width="30000" data-file-height="21059" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;"><a href="/wiki/Karl_Bryullov" title="Karl Bryullov">Karl Bryullov</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii" title="The Last Day of Pompeii">The Last Day of Pompeii</a></i> (1833)</span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:220px;max-width:220px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:130px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg/250px-Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="218" height="131" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg/330px-Winter_Palace_Panorama_3.jpg 1.5x, class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;">The <a href="/wiki/Winter_Palace" title="Winter Palace">Winter Palace</a> served as the <a href="/wiki/Official_residence" title="Official residence">official residence</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_all_the_Russias" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor of all the Russias">Emperor of Russia</a></span>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In the 1860s, a group of critical <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realists</a> (<a href="/wiki/Peredvizhniki" title="Peredvizhniki">Peredvizhniki</a>), led by <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Kramskoy" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Kramskoy">Ivan Kramskoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilya_Repin" title="Ilya Repin">Ilya Repin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vasiliy_Perov" class="mw-redirect" title="Vasiliy Perov">Vasiliy Perov</a> broke with the academy, and portrayed the many-sided aspects of social life in paintings.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-627" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-627"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>616<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-628" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-628"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>617<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The turn of the 20th century saw the rise of <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" class="mw-redirect" title="Symbolism (arts)">symbolism</a>, represented by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Vrubel" title="Mikhail Vrubel">Mikhail Vrubel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Roerich" title="Nicholas Roerich">Nicholas Roerich</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-629" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-629"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>618<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-630" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-630"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>619<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_avant-garde" title="Russian avant-garde">Russian avant-garde</a> flourished from approximately 1890 to 1930; globally influential artists from this era were <a href="/wiki/El_Lissitzky" title="El Lissitzky">El Lissitzky</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-631" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-631"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>620<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich" title="Kazimir Malevich">Kazimir Malevich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natalia_Goncharova" title="Natalia Goncharova">Natalia Goncharova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky" title="Wassily Kandinsky">Wassily Kandinsky</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marc_Chagall" title="Marc Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-632" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-632"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>621<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The history of <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Russia" title="Architecture of Russia">Russian architecture</a> begins with early woodcraft buildings of ancient Slavs and the <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Kievan_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of Kievan Rus&#39;">church architecture of Kievan Rus'</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-633" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-633"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>622<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus&#39;">Christianization of Kievan Rus'</a> brought centuries <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture#Legacy" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-634" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-634"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>623<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following Mongol occupation, Kievan Rus' cut its ties with the Byzantine Empire, and Russian architecture saw native innovations, such as the invention of the <a href="/wiki/Iconostasis" title="Iconostasis">iconostasis</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aristotle_Fioravanti" class="mw-redirect" title="Aristotle Fioravanti">Aristotle Fioravanti</a> and other Italian architects brought <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> trends to the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Principality_of_Moscow" title="Grand Principality of Moscow">Grand Principality of Moscow</a>, which influenced the reconstruction of the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin" class="mw-redirect" title="Moscow Kremlin">Moscow Kremlin</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-635" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-635"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>624<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 16th century saw the development of the unique <a href="/wiki/Tent-like_church" class="mw-redirect" title="Tent-like church">tent-like churches</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Onion_dome" title="Onion dome">onion dome</a> design, which is a distinctive feature of Russian architecture.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-636" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-636"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>625<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 17th century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow and <a href="/wiki/Yaroslavl" title="Yaroslavl">Yaroslavl</a>, gradually paving the way for the <a href="/wiki/Naryshkin_baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Naryshkin baroque">Naryshkin baroque</a> of the 1680s.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-637" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-637"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>626<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After the reforms of Peter the Great, Russia's architecture became influenced by Western European styles.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 18th-century taste for <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a> architecture led to the <a href="/wiki/Elizabethan_Baroque" title="Elizabethan Baroque">works</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Rastrelli" class="mw-redirect" title="Bartolomeo Rastrelli">Bartolomeo Rastrelli</a> and his followers. The most influential Russian architects of the eighteenth century, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Bazhenov" title="Vasily Bazhenov">Vasily Bazhenov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matvey_Kazakov" title="Matvey Kazakov">Matvey Kazakov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Starov" title="Ivan Starov">Ivan Starov</a>, created lasting monuments in Moscow and Saint Petersburg and established a base for the more Russian forms that followed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the reign of Catherine the Great, Saint Petersburg was transformed into an outdoor museum of <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-638" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-638"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>627<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Alexander I, <a href="/wiki/Empire_style" title="Empire style">Empire style</a> became the <i>de facto</i> architectural style.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-639" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-639"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>628<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The second half of the 19th century was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Byzantine_architecture_in_the_Russian_Empire" title="Neo-Byzantine architecture in the Russian Empire">Neo-Byzantine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Revival">Russian Revival</a> style.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture&#95;and&#95;Painting&#95;598-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998232233Architecture_and_Painting-598"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>587<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-640" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-640"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>629<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the early 20th century, <a href="/wiki/Russian_neoclassical_revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian neoclassical revival">Russian neoclassical revival</a> became a trend.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-641" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-641"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>630<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Prevalent styles of the late 20th century were <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau_architecture_in_Russia" title="Art Nouveau architecture in Russia">Art Nouveau</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-642" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-642"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>631<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Constructivism_(art)" title="Constructivism (art)">Constructivism</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-643" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-643"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>632<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Stalinist_architecture" title="Stalinist architecture">Socialist Classicism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-644" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-644"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>633<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Music">Music</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Russia" title="Music of Russia">Music of Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="231" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-Tchaikovsky_by_Reutlinger_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="883" data-file-height="1075" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a> (18401893), <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1888</span></figcaption></figure>
<p>Until the 18th century, music in Russia consisted mainly of church music and folk songs and dances.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998228230Music&#95;592-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998228230Music-592"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>581<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 19th century, it was defined by the tension between classical composer <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Glinka" title="Mikhail Glinka">Mikhail Glinka</a> along with other members of <a href="/wiki/The_Mighty_Handful" class="mw-redirect" title="The Mighty Handful">The Mighty Handful</a>, who were later succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Belyayev_circle" title="Belyayev circle">Belyayev circle</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-645" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-645"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>634<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Musical_Society" title="Russian Musical Society">Russian Musical Society</a> led by composers <a href="/wiki/Anton_Rubinstein" title="Anton Rubinstein">Anton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Rubinstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Rubinstein">Nikolay Rubinstein</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-646" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-646"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>635<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The later tradition of <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a>, one of the greatest composers of the Romantic era, was continued into the 20th century by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Rachmaninoff" title="Sergei Rachmaninoff">Sergei Rachmaninoff</a>. World-renowned composers of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Scriabin" title="Alexander Scriabin">Alexander Scriabin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Glazunov" title="Alexander Glazunov">Alexander Glazunov</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998228230Music&#95;592-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998228230Music-592"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>581<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev" title="Sergei Prokofiev">Sergei Prokofiev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Shostakovich" title="Dmitri Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a>, and later <a href="/wiki/Edison_Denisov" title="Edison Denisov">Edison Denisov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sofia_Gubaidulina" title="Sofia Gubaidulina">Sofia Gubaidulina</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-music2&#95;647-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-music2-647"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>636<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Georgy_Sviridov" title="Georgy Sviridov">Georgy Sviridov</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-648" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-648"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>637<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Schnittke" title="Alfred Schnittke">Alfred Schnittke</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-music2&#95;647-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-music2-647"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>636<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During the Soviet era, <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a> also produced a number of renowned figures, such as the two <a href="/wiki/Bard_(Soviet_Union)" title="Bard (Soviet Union)">balladeers</a><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vysotsky" title="Vladimir Vysotsky">Vladimir Vysotsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulat_Okudzhava" title="Bulat Okudzhava">Bulat Okudzhava</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-music2&#95;647-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-music2-647"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>636<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and performers such as <a href="/wiki/Alla_Pugacheva" title="Alla Pugacheva">Alla Pugacheva</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-649" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-649"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>638<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">Jazz</a>, even with sanctions from Soviet authorities, flourished and evolved into one of the country's most popular musical forms.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-music2&#95;647-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-music2-647"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>636<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By the 1980s, <a href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_Russia" title="Rock music in Russia">rock music</a> became popular across Russia, and produced bands such as <a href="/wiki/Aria_(band)" title="Aria (band)">Aria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aquarium_(band)" title="Aquarium (band)">Aquarium</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-650" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-650"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>639<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/DDT_(band)" title="DDT (band)">DDT</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-651" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-651"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>640<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kino_(band)" title="Kino (band)">Kino</a>;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-652" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-652"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>641<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the latter's leader <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Tsoi" title="Viktor Tsoi">Viktor Tsoi</a>, was in particular, a gigantic figure.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-653" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-653"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>642<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_pop" title="Russian pop">Pop music</a> has continued to flourish in Russia since the 1960s, with globally famous acts such as <a href="/wiki/T.A.T.u." title="T.A.T.u.">t.A.T.u.</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-654" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-654"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>643<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Novgorod_Codex_-_colour.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Novgorod_Codex_-_colour.jpg/250px-Novgorod_Codex_-_colour.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="300" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Novgorod_Codex_-_colour.jpg/500px-Novgorod_Codex_-_colour.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="780" data-file-height="937" /></a><figcaption>First page of the <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Codex" title="Novgorod Codex">Novgorod Codex</a> <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1000</span>, the oldest surviving book of Kievan Rus'</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a> is among the world's most influential and developed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-McLean-1962&#95;602-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McLean-1962-602"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>591<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It can be traced to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, when epics and chronicles in <a href="/wiki/Old_East_Slavic" title="Old East Slavic">Old East Slavic</a> were composed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-655" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-655"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>644<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>, literature had grown in importance, with works from <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Denis_Fonvizin" title="Denis Fonvizin">Denis Fonvizin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gavrila_Derzhavin" title="Gavrila Derzhavin">Gavrila Derzhavin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Karamzin" title="Nikolay Karamzin">Nikolay Karamzin</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From the early 1830s, during the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Russian_Poetry" title="Golden Age of Russian Poetry">Golden Age of Russian Poetry</a>, literature underwent an astounding golden age in poetry, prose and drama.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-656" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-656"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>645<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Romantic_literature" title="Romantic literature">Romantic literature</a> permitted a flowering of poetic talent: <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Zhukovsky" title="Vasily Zhukovsky">Vasily Zhukovsky</a> and later his protg <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a> came to the fore.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-657" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-657"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>646<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following Pushkin's footsteps, a new generation of poets were born, including <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lermontov" title="Mikhail Lermontov">Mikhail Lermontov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Nekrasov" title="Nikolay Nekrasov">Nikolay Nekrasov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aleksey_Konstantinovich_Tolstoy" title="Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy">Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Tyutchev" title="Fyodor Tyutchev">Fyodor Tyutchev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afanasy_Fet" title="Afanasy Fet">Afanasy Fet</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The first great Russian novelist was <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Gogol" title="Nikolai Gogol">Nikolai Gogol</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-658"
