class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-658"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>647<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Then, during the Age of <a href="/wiki/Literary_realism" title="Literary realism">Realism</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> came <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Turgenev" title="Ivan Turgenev">Ivan Turgenev</a>, who mastered both short stories and novels.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-659" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-659"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>648<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoyevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Fyodor Dostoyevsky">Fyodor Dostoevsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> soon became internationally renowned.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Saltykov-Shchedrin" title="Mikhail Saltykov-Shchedrin">Mikhail Saltykov-Shchedrin</a> wrote prose <a href="/wiki/Satire" title="Satire">satire</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-660" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-660"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>649<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Leskov" title="Nikolai Leskov">Nikolai Leskov</a> is best remembered for his shorter fiction.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-661" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-661"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>650<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the second half of the century <a href="/wiki/Anton_Chekhov" title="Anton Chekhov">Anton Chekhov</a> excelled in short stories and became a leading dramatist.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-662" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-662"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>651<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other important 19th-century developments included the fabulist <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Krylov" title="Ivan Krylov">Ivan Krylov</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-663" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-663"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>652<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> non-fiction writers such as the critic <a href="/wiki/Vissarion_Belinsky" title="Vissarion Belinsky">Vissarion Belinsky</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-664" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-664"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>653<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and playwrights such as <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Griboyedov" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksandr Griboyedov">Aleksandr Griboyedov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Ostrovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksandr Ostrovsky">Aleksandr Ostrovsky</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-665" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-665"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>654<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-666" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-666"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>655<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The beginning of the 20th century ranks as the <a href="/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Russian_Poetry" title="Silver Age of Russian Poetry">Silver Age of Russian Poetry</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This era had poets such as <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Blok" title="Alexander Blok">Alexander Blok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anna_Akhmatova" title="Anna Akhmatova">Anna Akhmatova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Pasternak" title="Boris Pasternak">Boris Pasternak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Mayakovsky" title="Vladimir Mayakovsky">Vladimir Mayakovsky</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-667" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-667"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>656<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Yesenin" title="Sergei Yesenin">Sergei Yesenin</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-668" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-668"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>657<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Balmont" title="Konstantin Balmont">Konstantin Balmont</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-669" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-669"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>658<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It also produced some first-rate novelists and short-story writers, such as <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Kuprin" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksandr Kuprin">Aleksandr Kuprin</a>, Nobel Prize winner <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Bunin" title="Ivan Bunin">Ivan Bunin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Andreyev" title="Leonid Andreyev">Leonid Andreyev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Zamyatin" title="Yevgeny Zamyatin">Yevgeny Zamyatin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Merezhkovsky" title="Dmitry Merezhkovsky">Dmitry Merezhkovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Bely" title="Andrei Bely">Andrei Bely</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After the Russian Revolution of 1917, Russian literature split into Soviet and <a href="/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9" title="White migr">white migr</a> parts. In the 1930s, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">Socialist realism</a> became the predominant trend in Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its leading figure was <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Gorky" title="Maxim Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a>, who laid the foundations of this style.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-670" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-670"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>659<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov" title="Mikhail Bulgakov">Mikhail Bulgakov</a> was one of the leading writers of the Soviet era.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-671" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-671"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>660<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Ostrovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Ostrovsky">Nikolay Ostrovsky</a>'s novel <a href="/wiki/How_the_Steel_Was_Tempered" title="How the Steel Was Tempered">How the Steel Was Tempered</a> has been among the most successful works of Russian literature.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Influential migr writers include <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Nabokov" title="Vladimir Nabokov">Vladimir Nabokov</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-672" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-672"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>661<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Asimov" title="Isaac Asimov">Isaac Asimov</a>, who was considered one of the "Big Three" science fiction writers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-673" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-673"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>662<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some writers dared to oppose Soviet ideology, such as Nobel Prize-winning novelist <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Solzhenitsyn" title="Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn">Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn</a>, who wrote about life in the Gulag camps.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-674" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-674"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>663<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:135px;max-width:135px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:189px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_(1844-1930)_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_(1887).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/250px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="133" height="190" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg/330px-Ilya_Efimovich_Repin_%281844-1930%29_-_Portrait_of_Leo_Tolstoy_%281887%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1711" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;"><a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> (18281910) is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time, with works such as <i><a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace" title="War and Peace">War and Peace</a></i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-675" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-675"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>664<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:153px;max-width:153px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:189px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/250px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="151" height="189" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="4000" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><span style="font-size:100%;"><a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoevsky" title="Fyodor Dostoevsky">Fyodor Dostoevsky</a> (18211881), one of the great novelists of all time, whose masterpieces include <i><a href="/wiki/Crime_and_Punishment" title="Crime and Punishment">Crime and Punishment</a></i><sup id="cite&#95;ref-676" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-676"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>665<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Russian literature faced rapid and difficult changes during the turbulent post-Soviet 1990s, with writers and publishers struggling to adjust to new economic and political developments.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-677" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-677"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>666<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Domestic literature subsequently declined in influence among most Russians,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature&#95;601-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis1998222228Literature-601"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>590<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> who now had sudden and rapid access to a wide volume of previously suppressed Western literary movements.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto&#95;678-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-678"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>667<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Nevertheless, this environment fostered experimental and postmodern literature and satire.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto&#95;678-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-678"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>667<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At the beginning of the 21st century, the most discussed figures, <a href="/wiki/Russian_postmodernism" title="Russian postmodernism">postmodernists</a> <a href="/wiki/Victor_Pelevin" title="Victor Pelevin">Victor Pelevin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Sorokin" title="Vladimir Sorokin">Vladimir Sorokin</a>, remained the leading Russian writers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-679" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-679"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>668<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a> has been influential. Religious and spiritual philosophy is represented by <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Solovyov_(philosopher)" title="Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)">Vladimir Solovyov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Berdyaev" title="Nikolai Berdyaev">Nikolai Berdyaev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pavel_Florensky" title="Pavel Florensky">Pavel Florensky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semyon_Frank" title="Semyon Frank">Semyon Frank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Lossky" title="Nikolay Lossky">Nikolay Lossky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Rozanov" title="Vasily Rozanov">Vasily Rozanov</a>, and others.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-680" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-680"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>669<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Mystic <a href="/wiki/Helena_Blavatsky" title="Helena Blavatsky">Helena Blavatsky</a> gained an international following as the leading theoretician of <a href="/wiki/Theosophy" title="Theosophy">Theosophy</a> and the co-founder of the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-681" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-681"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>670<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Herzen" title="Alexander Herzen">Alexander Herzen</a> is known as one of the fathers of <a href="/wiki/Agrarianism" title="Agrarianism">agrarian</a> <a href="/wiki/Populism" title="Populism">populism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-682" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-682"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>671<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bakunin" title="Mikhail Bakunin">Mikhail Bakunin</a> is referred to as the father of <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-683" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-683"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>672<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Kropotkin" title="Peter Kropotkin">Peter Kropotkin</a> was the most important theorist of <a href="/wiki/Anarcho-communism" class="mw-redirect" title="Anarcho-communism">anarcho-communism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-684" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-684"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>673<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bakhtin" title="Mikhail Bakhtin">Mikhail Bakhtin</a>'s writings have significantly inspired scholars in various fields.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-685" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-685"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>674<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, a major revolutionary, developed a variant of communism known as <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">Leninism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-686" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-686"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>675<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a>, Lenin's contemporary and co-revolutionary, founded his own strain of Marxism known as <a href="/wiki/Trotskyism" title="Trotskyism">Trotskyism</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-687" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-687"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>676<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Zinoviev" title="Alexander Zinoviev">Alexander Zinoviev</a> was a prominent philosopher and writer in the second half of the 20th century.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-688" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-688"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>677<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Mass_media_and_cinema">Mass media and cinema</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Russia">Media of Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Russia" title="Cinema of Russia">Cinema of Russia</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg/250px-%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="389" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg/330px-%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg/500px-%D0%9E%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F_%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6443" data-file-height="13187" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Ostankino_Tower" title="Ostankino Tower">Ostankino Tower</a> in Moscow, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_freestanding_structures" title="List of tallest freestanding structures">tallest freestanding structure</a> in Europe<sup id="cite&#95;ref-689" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-689"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>678<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>There are 400 news agencies in Russia, among which the largest internationally operating are <a href="/wiki/TASS" title="TASS">TASS</a>, <a href="/wiki/RIA_Novosti" title="RIA Novosti">RIA Novosti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_(news_agency)" title="Sputnik (news agency)">Sputnik</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Interfax" title="Interfax">Interfax</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-690" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-690"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>679<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Russia" title="Television in Russia">Television</a> is the most popular medium in Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-bbcmedia&#95;691-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcmedia-691"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>680<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Among the 3,000 licensed radio stations nationwide, notable ones include <a href="/wiki/Radio_Rossii" title="Radio Rossii">Radio Rossii</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vesti_FM" title="Vesti FM">Vesti FM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Echo_of_Moscow" title="Echo of Moscow">Echo of Moscow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radio_Mayak" title="Radio Mayak">Radio Mayak</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russkoye_Radio" title="Russkoye Radio">Russkoye Radio</a>. Of the 16,000 registered newspapers, <span title="Russian-language text"><i lang="ru-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Argumenty_i_Fakty" title="Argumenty i Fakty">Argumenty i Fakty</a></i></span>, <span title="Russian-language text"><i lang="ru-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Komsomolskaya_Pravda" title="Komsomolskaya Pravda">Komsomolskaya Pravda</a></i></span>, <span title="Russian-language text"><i lang="ru-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Rossiyskaya_Gazeta" title="Rossiyskaya Gazeta">Rossiyskaya Gazeta</a></i></span>, <i><a href="/wiki/Izvestia" title="Izvestia">Izvestia</a></i>, and <span title="Russian-language text"><i lang="ru-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Moskovskij_Komsomolets" title="Moskovskij Komsomolets">Moskovskij Komsomolets</a></i></span> are popular. State-run <a href="/wiki/Channel_One_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Channel One Russia">Channel One</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia-1" title="Russia-1">Russia-1</a> are the leading news channels, while <a href="/wiki/RT_(TV_network)" title="RT (TV network)">RT</a> is the flagship of Russia's international media operations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-bbcmedia&#95;691-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcmedia-691"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>680<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has the <a href="/wiki/Video_games_in_Russia" title="Video games in Russia">largest video gaming market</a> in Europe, with over 65 million players nationwide.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-692" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-692"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>681<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russian and later <a href="/wiki/Soviet_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet cinema">Soviet cinema</a> was a hotbed of invention, resulting in world-renowned films such as <i><a href="/wiki/Battleship_Potemkin" title="Battleship Potemkin">Battleship Potemkin</a></i>, which was named the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" class="mw-redirect" title="List of films considered the best">greatest film of all time</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Expo_58" title="Expo 58">Brussels World's Fair</a> in 1958.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-693" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-693"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>682<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-694" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-694"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>683<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Soviet-era filmmakers, most notably <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Eisenstein" title="Sergei Eisenstein">Sergei Eisenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Tarkovsky" title="Andrei Tarkovsky">Andrei Tarkovsky</a>, would go on to become among of the world's most innovative and influential directors.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-695" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-695"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>684<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-696" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-696"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>685<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Eisenstein was a student of <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kuleshov" title="Lev Kuleshov">Lev Kuleshov</a>, who developed the groundbreaking <a href="/wiki/Soviet_montage_theory" title="Soviet montage theory">Soviet montage theory</a> of film editing at the world's first film school, the <a href="/wiki/Gerasimov_Institute_of_Cinematography" title="Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography">All-Union Institute of Cinematography</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-697" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-697"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>686<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dziga_Vertov" title="Dziga Vertov">Dziga Vertov</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Kino-Eye" title="Kino-Eye">Kino-Eye</a>" theory had a large effect on the development of documentary filmmaking and cinema realism.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-698" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-698"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>687<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Many Soviet socialist realism films were artistically successful, including <i><a href="/wiki/Chapaev_(film)" title="Chapaev (film)">Chapaev</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cranes_Are_Flying" title="The Cranes Are Flying">The Cranes Are Flying</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Ballad_of_a_Soldier" title="Ballad of a Soldier">Ballad of a Soldier</a></i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bulgakova-2012&#95;600-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bulgakova-2012-600"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>589<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bulgakova-2012&#95;600-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bulgakova-2012-600"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>589<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The comedies of <a href="/wiki/Eldar_Ryazanov" title="Eldar Ryazanov">Eldar Ryazanov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Gaidai" title="Leonid Gaidai">Leonid Gaidai</a> were immensely popular, with many of their catchphrases still in use today.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-699" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-699"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>688<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-700" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-700"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>689<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 196168 <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Bondarchuk" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Bondarchuk">Sergey Bondarchuk</a> directed an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Oscar</a>-winning <a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace_(film_series)" title="War and Peace (film series)">film adaptation</a> of Leo Tolstoy's epic <i><a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace" title="War and Peace">War and Peace</a></i>, which was <a href="/wiki/The_most_expensive_film" class="mw-redirect" title="The most expensive film">the most expensive film</a> made in the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Bulgakova-2012&#95;600-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bulgakova-2012-600"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>589<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1969, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Motyl" title="Vladimir Motyl">Vladimir Motyl</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/White_Sun_of_the_Desert" title="White Sun of the Desert">White Sun of the Desert</a></i> was released, a very popular film in a genre of <a href="/wiki/Ostern" title="Ostern">ostern</a>; the film is traditionally watched by <a href="/wiki/Cosmonauts" class="mw-redirect" title="Cosmonauts">cosmonauts</a> before any trip into space.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-701" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-701"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>690<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Russian cinema industry suffered large losses; however, since the late 2000s, it has seen growth once again, and continues to expand.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-702" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-702"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>691<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cuisine">Cuisine</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/250px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Mint_bread_kvas.jpg/500px-Mint_bread_kvas.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2628" data-file-height="1971" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">Kvass</a> is an ancient and traditional Russian beverage.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Russian cuisine has been formed by the country's diverse climate, cultural and religious traditions, and vast geography; it shares similarities with neighbouring countries. Crops of <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, wheat, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Millet" title="Millet">millet</a> provide the ingredients for various breads, <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a> and cereals, as well as for many drinks. <a href="/wiki/Bread_in_Europe#Finland_and_Russia" title="Bread in Europe">Bread</a>, of many varieties,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-703" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-703"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>692<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> is very popular across Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-704" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-704"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>693<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Flavourful soups and stews include <a href="/wiki/Shchi" title="Shchi">shchi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Borsch" class="mw-redirect" title="Borsch">borsch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukha" title="Ukha">ukha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solyanka" title="Solyanka">solyanka</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Okroshka" title="Okroshka">okroshka</a>. <a href="/wiki/Smetana_(dairy_product)" title="Smetana (dairy product)">Smetana</a> (a heavy <a href="/wiki/Sour_cream" title="Sour cream">sour cream</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Mayonnaise" title="Mayonnaise">mayonnaise</a> are often added to soups and salads.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-705" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-705"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>694<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-706" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-706"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>695<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pirozhki" title="Pirozhki">Pirozhki</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-707" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-707"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>696<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Blini" title="Blini">blini</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-708" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-708"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>697<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Syrniki" title="Syrniki">syrniki</a> are native types of <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-709" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-709"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>698<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Beef_Stroganoff" title="Beef Stroganoff">Beef Stroganoff</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Volokh-1983&#95;710-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Volokh-1983-710"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>699<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 266">&#58;&#8202;266&#8202;</span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chicken_Kiev" title="Chicken Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Volokh-1983&#95;710-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Volokh-1983-710"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>699<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 320">&#58;&#8202;320&#8202;</span></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pelmeni" title="Pelmeni">pelmeni</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-711" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-711"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>700<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Shashlyk" class="mw-redirect" title="Shashlyk">shashlyk</a> are popular meat dishes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-712" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-712"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>701<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls (<a href="/wiki/Golubtsy" class="mw-redirect" title="Golubtsy">golubtsy</a>) usually filled with meat.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-713" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-713"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>702<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Salads include <a href="/wiki/Olivier_salad" title="Olivier salad">Olivier salad</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-714" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-714"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>703<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vinegret" title="Vinegret">vinegret</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-715" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-715"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>704<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Dressed_herring" title="Dressed herring">dressed herring</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-716" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-716"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>705<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_drinks" title="List of national drinks">national non-alcoholic drink</a> is <a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">kvass</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-717" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-717"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>706<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the national alcoholic drink is <a href="/wiki/Vodka" title="Vodka">vodka</a>; its production in Russia (and elsewhere) dates back to the 14th century.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-718" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-718"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>707<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country has the world's highest vodka consumption,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-719" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-719"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>708<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Beer_in_Russia" title="Beer in Russia">beer</a> is the most popular alcoholic beverage.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-720" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-720"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>709<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_wine" title="Russian wine">Wine</a> has become increasingly popular in Russia in the 21st century.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-721" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-721"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>710<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_tea_culture" title="Russian tea culture">Tea has been popular in Russia</a> for centuries.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-722" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-722"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>711<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Sports">Sports</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Russia" title="Sport in Russia">Sport in Russia</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is the most popular sport in Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-723" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-723"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>712<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team" title="Soviet Union national football team">Soviet Union national football team</a> became the first European champions by winning <a href="/wiki/Euro_1960" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 1960">Euro 1960</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-724" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-724"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>713<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and reached the finals of <a href="/wiki/Euro_1988" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 1988">Euro 1988</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-725" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-725"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>714<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russian clubs <a href="/wiki/PFC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PFC CSKA Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zenit_Saint_Petersburg" class="mw-redirect" title="Zenit Saint Petersburg">Zenit Saint Petersburg</a> won the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in 2005 and 2008.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-726" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-726"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>715<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-727" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-727"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>716<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national football team">Russian national football team</a> reached the semi-finals of <a href="/wiki/Euro_2008" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2008">Euro 2008</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-728" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-728"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>717<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia was the host nation for the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">2017 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-729" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-729"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>718<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-730" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-730"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>719<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Russian teams are currently suspended from FIFA and UEFA competitions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-731" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-731"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>720<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Maria_Sharapova_(18405201199).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg/250px-Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="183" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg/500px-Maria_Sharapova_%2818405201199%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4483" data-file-height="3287" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>, former <a href="/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_tennis_players" class="mw-redirect" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked tennis players">world No. 1</a> tennis player, was the world's highest-paid female athlete for 11 consecutive years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-732" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-732"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>721<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey_in_Russia" title="Ice hockey in Russia">Ice hockey</a> is very popular in Russia, and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Soviet Union men&#39;s national ice hockey team">Soviet national ice hockey team</a> dominated the sport internationally throughout its existence.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Riordan-1993&#95;597-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Riordan-1993-597"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>586<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bandy" title="Bandy">Bandy</a> is Russia's national sport, and it has historically been the highest-achieving country in the sport.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-733" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-733"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>722<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national basketball team">Russian national basketball team</a> won <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2007" title="EuroBasket 2007">EuroBasket 2007</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-734" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-734"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>723<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the Russian basketball club <a href="/wiki/PBC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PBC CSKA Moscow">PBC CSKA Moscow</a> is among the most successful European basketball teams.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-735" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-735"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>724<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The annual Formula One <a href="/wiki/Russian_Grand_Prix" title="Russian Grand Prix">Russian Grand Prix</a> was held at the <a href="/wiki/Sochi_Autodrom" class="mw-redirect" title="Sochi Autodrom">Sochi Autodrom</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sochi_Olympic_Park" title="Sochi Olympic Park">Sochi Olympic Park</a>, until its termination following the <a href="/wiki/2022_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine">2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-736" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-736"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>725<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-737" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-737"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>726<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, <a href="/wiki/Russia_at_the_Olympics" title="Russia at the Olympics">Russian athletes</a> have been one of the most successful contenders in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Riordan-1993&#95;597-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Riordan-1993-597"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>586<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia is the leading nation in <a href="/wiki/Rhythmic_gymnastics" title="Rhythmic gymnastics">rhythmic gymnastics</a>, and Russian <a href="/wiki/Synchronised_swimming" class="mw-redirect" title="Synchronised swimming">synchronised swimming</a> is considered to be the world's best.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-738" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-738"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>727<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">Figure skating</a> is another popular sport in Russia, especially <a href="/wiki/Pair_skating" title="Pair skating">pair skating</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ice_dancing" class="mw-redirect" title="Ice dancing">ice dancing</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-739" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-739"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>728<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Russia has produced numerous prominent tennis players.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-740" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-740"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>729<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is also a widely popular pastime in the nation, with many of the world's top chess players being Russian for decades.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-741" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-741"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>730<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympic_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="1980 Summer Olympic Games">1980 Summer Olympic Games</a> were held in Moscow,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-742" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-742"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>731<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Paralympics" title="2014 Winter Paralympics">2014 Winter Paralympics</a> were hosted in Sochi.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-743" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-743"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>732<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-744" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-744"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>733<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Russia has also had 43 <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">Olympic medals</a> stripped from its athletes due to <a href="/wiki/Doping_in_Russia" title="Doping in Russia">doping violations</a>, which is the most of any country, and nearly a third of the global total.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-745" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-745"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>734<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1266661725">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0;margin:0.5em 0;display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;list-style:none}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:1px solid var(--border-color-base,#a2a9b1);padding:0.1em;background:var(--background-color-neutral-subtle,#f8f9fa)}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-entry{display:table-row;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;height:1.9em;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-image{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-link{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .portalleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalright{clear:right;float:right;margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}}</style><ul role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portalbox portalborder portalright">
<li class="portalbox-entry"><span class="portalbox-image"><span class="mw-image-border noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/40px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/60px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Flag_of_Russia.svg/120px-Flag_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></span></span></span><span class="portalbox-link"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Russia" title="Portal:Russia">Russia portal</a></span></li><li class="portalbox-entry"><span class="portalbox-image"><span class="noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:P_countries-vector.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/P_countries-vector.svg/40px-P_countries-vector.svg.png" decoding="async" width="31" height="28" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/P_countries-vector.svg/60px-P_countries-vector.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/P_countries-vector.svg/120px-P_countries-vector.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="360" /></a></span></span><span class="portalbox-link"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Countries" title="Portal:Countries">Countries portal</a></span></li></ul>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Russia" title="Outline of Russia">Outline of Russia</a><div style="clear:both;" class=""></div></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1327269900">.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}body.skin-vector-2022 .mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:27em}body.skin-vector-2022 .mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:22.5em}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=upper-alpha]{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=upper-roman]{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-alpha]{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-greek]{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-roman]{list-style-type:lower-roman}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-upper-alpha .references{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-upper-roman .references{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-alpha .references{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-greek .references{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-roman .references{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div>
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references" data-mw-group="lower-alpha">
<li id="cite&#95;note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, which was <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexed by Russia</a> in 2014, remains <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262">internationally recognised</a> as a part of Ukraine.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Pifer-2020&#95;1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pifer-2020-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson, and Zaporizhzhia oblasts, which were <a href="/wiki/Russian_annexation_of_Donetsk,_Kherson,_Luhansk_and_Zaporizhzhia_oblasts" title="Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts">annexed</a>though are only partially occupiedin 2022, also remain <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_ES-11/4" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution ES-11/4">internationally recognised</a> as a part of Ukraine. The southernmost <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a> have been the subject of a <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands_dispute" title="Kuril Islands dispute">territorial dispute</a> with Japan since their occupation by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Chapple-2019&#95;2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chapple-2019-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>: <span lang="ru"></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">romanised</a>:&#160;</small><span title="Russian-language romanisation"><i lang="ru-Latn">Rossiya</i></span>, <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="ru-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">&#91;rsij&#93;</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>: <span lang="ru"> </span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">romanised</a>:&#160;</small><span title="Russian-language romanisation"><i lang="ru-Latn">Rossiyskaya Federatsiya</i></span>, <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">IPA:</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="ru-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">&#91;rsijskj<span class="wrap"> </span>fdratsj&#93;</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The fourteen countries bordering Russia are<sup id="cite&#95;ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> to the northwest; <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> to the west, as well as <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> (with <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">Kaliningrad Oblast</a>); <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> to the southwest; <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a> to the south; <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> to the southeast. Russia also shares <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime boundaries</a> with Japan and the United States. Russia also shares borders with the two <a href="/wiki/Partially_recognized_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Partially recognized states">partially recognised</a> breakaway states of <a href="/wiki/South_Ossetia" title="South Ossetia">South Ossetia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abkhazia" title="Abkhazia">Abkhazia</a> that it occupies in Georgia.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-190"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-190">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Most notably the <a href="/wiki/Budyonnovsk_hospital_hostage_crisis" title="Budyonnovsk hospital hostage crisis">Budyonnovsk hospital hostage crisis</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_apartment_bombings" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian apartment bombings">Russian apartment bombings</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_theater_hostage_crisis" title="Moscow theater hostage crisis">Moscow theatre hostage crisis</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Beslan_school_siege" title="Beslan school siege">Beslan school siege</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-230">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia has an additional 850&#160;km (530&#160;mi) of coastline along the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>, which is the world's largest inland body of water, and has been variously classified as a sea or a lake.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-233"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-233">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia, by land area, is larger than the continents of <a href="/wiki/Australia_(continent)" title="Australia (continent)">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, and Europe, although it covers a large part of the latter itself. Its land area could be roughly compared to that of South America.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-238">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Russia borders, clockwise, to its southwest: the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a>, to its west: the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, to its north: the <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">Barents Sea</a> (<a href="/wiki/White_Sea" title="White Sea">White Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pechora_Sea" title="Pechora Sea">Pechora Sea</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Kara_Sea" title="Kara Sea">Kara Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Laptev_Sea" title="Laptev Sea">Laptev Sea</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Siberian_Sea" title="East Siberian Sea">East Siberian Sea</a>, to its northeast: the <a href="/wiki/Chukchi_Sea" title="Chukchi Sea">Chukchi Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bering_Sea" title="Bering Sea">Bering Sea</a>, and to its southeast: the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-265"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-265">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 2020, <a href="/wiki/2020_amendments_to_the_Constitution_of_Russia" title="2020 amendments to the Constitution of Russia">constitutional amendments</a> were signed into law that limit the president to two terms overall rather than two consecutive terms, with this limit reset for current and previous presidents.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-disputed-289"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-disputed_289-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including bodies on territory disputed between Russia and Ukraine whose annexation has not been internationally recognised: the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea_(Russia)" title="Republic of Crimea (Russia)">Republic of Crimea</a> and the federal city of <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a> since the annexation of Crimea in 2014,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Pifer-2020&#95;1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pifer-2020-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and territories set up following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_annexation_of_Donetsk,_Kherson,_Luhansk_and_Zaporizhzhia_oblasts" title="Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts">Russian annexation of Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts</a> in 2022.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-ArenaAtlasIslam-558"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlasIslam_558-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Sreda Arena Atlas 2012 did not count the populations of two federal subjects of Russia where the majority of the population is Muslim, namely <a href="/wiki/Chechnya" title="Chechnya">Chechnya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ingushetia" title="Ingushetia">Ingushetia</a>, which together had a population of nearly 2 million, thus the proportion of Muslims was possibly slightly underestimated.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ArenaAtlas2012&#95;546-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-546"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>536<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite&#95;note-gks.ru-popul-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-gks.ru-popul_15-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-gks.ru-popul_15-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://rosstat.gov.ru/storage/mediabank/PrPopul2025_Site.xlsx"><bdi lang="ru">       1  2025 </bdi></a> &#91;Preliminary estimate of the permanent population as of January 1, 2025&#93; <span class="cs1-format">(XLSX)</span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Federal_State_Statistics_Service_(Russia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal State Statistics Service (Russia)">Russian Federal State Statistics Service</a></i> (in Russian). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20250407172042/https://rosstat.gov.ru/storage/mediabank/PrPopul2025_Site.xlsx">Archived</a> from the original on 7 April 2025<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFNazarenko2001" class="citation book cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Nazarenko" title="Aleksandr Nazarenko">Nazarenko, Aleksandr Vasilevich</a> (2001). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110814143443/http://dgve.csu.ru/download/Nazarenko_2001_01.djvu">"1.  ""      (XIXII )"</a> &#91;The name Rus' in the old tradition of Western European language (XI-XII centuries)&#93;.  <bdi lang="ru">    :   , ,   IXXII </bdi> &#91;<i>Ancient Rus' on international routes: interdisciplinary essays on cultural, trade, and political ties in the 9th12th centuries</i>&#93; (in Russian). Languages of the Rus' culture. pp.&#160;40, <span class="nowrap">42</span>45, <span class="nowrap">49</span>50. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-5-7859-0085-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-5-7859-0085-1"><bdi>978-5-7859-0085-1</bdi></a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://dgve.csu.ru/download/Nazarenko_2001_01.djvu">the original</a> on 14 August 2011.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=1.+%D0%98%D0%BC%D1%8F+%22%D0%A0%D1%83%D1%81%D1%8C%22+%D0%B2+%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B5%D0%B9%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%B9+%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%B9%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9+%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8B%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9+%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8+%28XI%E2%80%93XII+%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B0%29&amp;rft.btitle=%D0%94%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8F%D1%8F+%D0%A0%D1%83%D1%81%D1%8C+%D0%BD%D0%B0+%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%8B%D1%85+%D0%BF%D1%83%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%85%3A+%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B5+%D0%BE%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%B8+%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%82%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8B%D1%85%2C+%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8B%D1%85%2C+%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D1%85+%D1%81%D0%B2%D1%8F%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9+IX%E2%80%93XII+%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2&amp;rft.pages=40%2C+42-45%2C+49-50&amp;rft.pub=Languages+of+the+Rus%27+culture&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-5-7859-0085-1&amp;rft.aulast=Nazarenko&amp;rft.aufirst=Aleksandr+Vasilevich&amp;rft&#95;id=http%3A%2F%2Fdgve.csu.ru%2Fdownload%2FNazarenko&#95;2001&#95;01.djvu&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMilner-Gulland1997" class="citation book cs1">Milner-Gulland, R. R. (1997). <i>The Russians: The People of Europe</i>. Blackwell Publishing. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">1</span>4. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-631-21849-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-631-21849-4"><bdi>978-0-631-21849-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Russians%3A+The+People+of+Europe&amp;rft.pages=1-4&amp;rft.pub=Blackwell+Publishing&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-631-21849-4&amp;rft.aulast=Milner-Gulland&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+R.&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-33">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFObolensky1971" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Dimitri_Obolensky" title="Dimitri Obolensky">Obolensky, Dimitri</a> (1971). "Commentary on the ninth chapter of Constantine Porphyrogenitus' De Administrando lmperio". <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=wH4JAQAAIAAJ"><i>Byzantium and the Slavs: Collected Studies</i></a>. Variorum Reprints. p.&#160;20. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-902089-14-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-902089-14-3"><bdi>978-0-902089-14-3</bdi></a>. <q>Later, the term <i></i> was borrowed by the Russians, in the form <i>Rosiya</i>, from the terminology used by the Byzantine Patriarchate.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Commentary+on+the+ninth+chapter+of+Constantine+Porphyrogenitus%27+De+Administrando+lmperio&amp;rft.btitle=Byzantium+and+the+Slavs%3A+Collected+Studies&amp;rft.pages=20&amp;rft.pub=Variorum+Reprints&amp;rft.date=1971&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-902089-14-3&amp;rft.aulast=Obolensky&amp;rft.aufirst=Dimitri&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DwH4JAQAAIAAJ&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBushkovitch2011" class="citation book cs1">Bushkovitch, Paul (5 December 2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Le-n7ZYjGWkC"><i>A Concise History of Russia</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;37. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-139-50444-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-139-50444-7"><bdi>978-1-139-50444-7</bdi></a>. <q>Precisely at this time in written usage the modern term <i>Rossia</i> (a literary expression borrowed from Greek) began to edge out the traditional and vernacular <i>Rus</i>.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Concise+History+of+Russia&amp;rft.pages=37&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2011-12-05&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-139-50444-7&amp;rft.aulast=Bushkovitch&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLe-n7ZYjGWkC&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFDouka2019" class="citation journal cs1">Douka, K. (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://amu.hal.science/hal-03207786">"Age estimates for hominin fossils and the onset of the Upper Palaeolithic at Denisova Cave"</a>. <i>Nature</i>. <b>565</b> (7741): <span class="nowrap">640</span>644. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019Natur.565..640D">2019Natur.565..640D</a>. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fs41586-018-0870-z">10.1038/s41586-018-0870-z</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30700871">30700871</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Age+estimates+for+hominin+fossils+and+the+onset+of+the+Upper+Palaeolithic+at+Denisova+Cave&amp;rft.volume=565&amp;rft.issue=7741&amp;rft.pages=640-644&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Apmid%2F30700871&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fs41586-018-0870-z&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Abibcode%2F2019Natur.565..640D&amp;rft.aulast=Douka&amp;rft.aufirst=K.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Famu.hal.science%2Fhal-03207786&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFWarren2018" class="citation journal cs1">Warren, Matthew (22 August 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fd41586-018-06004-0">"Mum's a Neanderthal, Dad's a Denisovan: First discovery of an ancient-human hybrid"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>. <b>560</b> (7719): <span class="nowrap">417</span>418. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018Natur.560..417W">2018Natur.560..417W</a>. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fd41586-018-06004-0">10.1038/d41586-018-06004-0</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30135540">30135540</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Mum%27s+a+Neanderthal%2C+Dad%27s+a+Denisovan%3A+First+discovery+of+an+ancient-human+hybrid&amp;rft.volume=560&amp;rft.issue=7719&amp;rft.pages=417-418&amp;rft.date=2018-08-22&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Apmid%2F30135540&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fd41586-018-06004-0&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Abibcode%2F2018Natur.560..417W&amp;rft.aulast=Warren&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1038%252Fd41586-018-06004-0&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFIgor&#95;V.&#95;OvchinnikovAnders&#95;GtherstrmGalina&#95;P.&#95;RomanovaVitaliy&#95;M.&#95;Kharitonov2000" class="citation journal cs1">Igor V. Ovchinnikov; Anders Gtherstrm; Galina P. Romanova; Vitaliy M. Kharitonov; Kerstin Lidn; William Goodwin (30 March 2000). <li id="cite&#95;note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFPavlovJohn&#95;Inge&#95;SvendsenSvein&#95;Indrelid2001" class="citation journal cs1">Pavlov, Pavel; John Inge Svendsen; Svein Indrelid (6 September 2001). <li id="cite&#95;note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBalter2013" class="citation journal cs1">Balter, M. <li id="cite&#95;note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGibbons2017" class="citation journal cs1">Gibbons, Ann (21 February 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.science.org/content/article/thousands-horsemen-may-have-swept-bronze-age-europe-transforming-local-population">"Thousands of horsemen may have swept into Bronze Age Europe, transforming the local population"</a>. <i>Science</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220925154535/https://www.science.org/content/article/thousands-horsemen-may-have-swept-bronze-age-europe-transforming-local-population">Archived</a> from the original on 25 September 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-78">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFAnderson2014" class="citation book cs1">Anderson, M.S. <li id="cite&#95;note-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-104">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFVincent1981" class="citation journal cs1">Vincent, J.R. <li id="cite&#95;note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFWalsh1928" class="citation web cs1"><a href="/wiki/Edmund_A._Walsh" title="Edmund A. <li id="cite&#95;note-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-116">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMosse1964" class="citation journal cs1">Mosse, W. E. (April 1964). <li id="cite&#95;note-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-127">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGetty1986" class="citation journal cs1">Getty, J Arch. <li id="cite&#95;note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-128">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBensley2014" class="citation web cs1">Bensley, Michael (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://kar.kent.ac.uk/47659/1/Socialism%20in%20One%20Country%20Redacted.pdf">"Socialism in One Country: A Study of Pragmatism and Ideology in the Soviet 1920s"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/University_of_Kent" title="University of Kent">University of Kent</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210626142120/https://kar.kent.ac.uk/47659/1/Socialism%20in%20One%20Country%20Redacted.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 26 June 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-129">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFKuromiya2005" class="citation journal cs1">Kuromiya, Hirosaki (2005). <li id="cite&#95;note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFStolfi1982" class="citation journal cs1">Stolfi, Russel H. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFWilson2018" class="citation book cs1">Wilson, David (2018). <i>The Eastern Front Campaign: An Operational Level Analysis</i>. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-Reiman-2016-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Reiman-2016_156-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Reiman-2016_156-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFReiman2016" class="citation book cs1">Reiman, Michael (2016). <li id="cite&#95;note-168"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-168">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFWestad1994" class="citation journal cs1">Westad, Odd Arne (February 1994). <li id="cite&#95;note-169"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-169">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFDaley1989" class="citation journal cs1">Daley, Tad (May 1989). "Afghanistan and Gorbachev's Global Foreign Policy". <i><a href="/wiki/Asian_Survey" title="Asian Survey">Asian Survey</a></i>. <b>29</b> (5). <a href="/wiki/University_of_California_Press" title="University of California Press">University of California Press</a>: <span class="nowrap">496</span>513. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F2644534">10.2307/2644534</a>. <a href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/2644534">2644534</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Asian+Survey&amp;rft.atitle=Afghanistan+and+Gorbachev%27s+Global+Foreign+Policy&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.pages=496-513&amp;rft.date=1989-05&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F2644534&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F2644534%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Daley&amp;rft.aufirst=Tad&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-181"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-181">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFHollander1997" class="citation journal cs1">Hollander, D. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-182"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-182">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFChenWittgensteinMcKeon1996" class="citation journal cs1">Chen, Lincoln C.; Wittgenstein, Friederike; McKeon, Elizabeth (September 1996).
